properties.Name: Old Bank of the State of South Carolina
properties.Description: 1 Broad St. The original construction of the building cost an estimated $100,000. The bank was moved to Cannon St. during the Civil War. Its financial collapse coincided with the end of the war. Each lion head keystone is distinctive.

properties.Name: The Old News and Courier Building
properties.Description: 19 Broad St. It wasn't until the South Western Railroad Bank moved into the building in 1840 that the granite facade was added. The facade might have been designed by Nathaniel F. Potter. The earthquake of 1886 brought many of the granite blocks crashing down onto the street, some with such force that they broke water mains.

properties.Name: Plenge Haberdashery
properties.Description: 43 Broad St. Built by Charles Love and Conrad M. Wienges. They made saddles and harnesses. The building was sold to Charles Plenge in 1870 and named Plenge Haberdashery. Notice "The Hat Man" facing Church St. Try and find 16 hats in the mural.

properties.Name: The Daniel Ravenel House
properties.Description: 68 Broad St. Isaac Mazyck bought the lot in 1710 and willed it in 1749 to his daughter, Charlotte. In 1759, Charlotte married Daniel Ravenel. Much of the land that Ravenel and his relatives owned for cutting timber and growing crops went under water after the Santee River was dammed to create Lake Moultrie. Daniel and Charlotte Ravenel built the house at 68 Broad to replace one that was destroyed by a fire in 1796. The property is still owned by the Ravenel family, thus it is currently the city's oldest continuing legacy property.

properties.Name: U.S. Post Office and Federal District courtroom
properties.Description: 83 Broad St. U.S. Post Office and Federal District courtroom (2nd floor) along with 85-87 Broad. SW Four Corners of Law. The site has been used for a number of purposes, including a guardhouse for the colonial government. The gates for the guardhouse are now at The Citadel and 32 Legare ("The Sword House"). The building standing now was constructed beginning in 1886 after the earthquake. The granite is from Winnsboro, SC. 85-87 Broad is the Hollings Judicial Annex named in honor of South Carolina's U.S. senator, Ernest Hollings (1922-2019). The statue in the park is of Supreme Court justice James F. Byrnes (1882 - 1972).

properties.Name: William Harvey House
properties.Description: 110 Broad St. Joel Roberts Poinsett bought the house in 1837. Joel Roberts Poinsett (1779 - 1851) worked as a U.S. diplomat in Argentina, Chile, and Mexico. He served in the S.C. General Assembly and the U.S. Congress. He was the Secretary of War under Martin Van Buren. Poinsett also led the Unionist or anti-Nullification party. When not dealing with war and politics, he served a mean breakfast. He also studied and collected plants. In 1828, he brought to Charleston from South America the flower that is now known as the poinsettia (Euphorbia pulcherrima)

properties.Name: First Baptist Church
properties.Description: 61 Church St. First Baptist Church, “the Mother Church of Southern Baptists.” A Baptist congregation from Kittery, Maine, followed minister William Screven in 1682 to Charleston to establish a church in Charleston. During the Revolutionary War, the British used the church for storage. The present-day church was constructed from 1819-1822. Note the Greek style with Tuscan columns and Roman arches. Richard Furman (1755-1825) served as the church's pastor from 1786 until his death in 1825. Prior to serving at First Baptist, he worked and spoke to gain support for the Patriot cause. England's Lord Cornwallis feared Furman’s prayers and sermons more than he did “the armies of Marion and Sumter.” When Charleston fell to the British in 1780, Cornwallis placed a bounty of £1,000 on Furman's capture. Furman was never caught. The university named in his honor was founded in 1826

properties.Name: William Stone House
properties.Description: 83 East Bay. William Stone was an English merchant and a Tory. The building passed through a succession of merchants until Susan Pringle Frost bought the house in 1941. She rehabilitated the house and gutted the brick warehouse in the back. Loutrel Briggs designed the courtyard garden in the back that incorporates the walls of the warehouse.

properties.Name: John O' Mara House
properties.Description: 82 Queen. John O' Mara House. John O' Mara also built 78 Queen St. During the 1870s, 82 Queen was the law office for Jonathan Jasper Wright. Wright was a native of Pennsylvania. The American Missionary Association assigned Wright to Charleston to help organize training programs and schools for former slaves. Wright was the only person of African descent on the S.C. State Supreme Court during Reconstruction. Wright was also a law professor at Claflin College in Orangeburg. One of most well known restaurants in Charleston today uses the street address for its name.

properties.Name: Memminger Auditorium
properties.Description: 22 Beaufain St. Memminger Auditorium. The auditorium stands on glebe lands of the Episcopal Church. The church first used the site for a school and parsonage beginning in 1744. The Normal School for the training of female teachers was built on the site in 1858. In 1899, The City Board of School Commissioners bought the property. The name of the The Normal School was changed to the Memminger High School in honor of Christopher Gustavus Memminger (1803-1888). In 1953, the Memminger High School was torn down. It was replaced by the Memminger Elementary School within the Charleston County Public School District. The school was torn down in 2008. The school and the auditorium were re-built from 2008 - 2011. The Spoleto Music Festival also uses the auditorium.

properties.Name: Old High School of Charleston
properties.Description: 55 Society St. Old High School of Charleston. The Corinthian capitals replaced those that were destroyed by the earthquake of 1886. In 1881, the High School of Charleston was re-located to the Radcliffe-King Mansion at 24 George Street. The former high school is now condominiums.

properties.Name: Francis Nelson House
properties.Description: 6 Alexander St. Francis Nelson House. Nelson was a ship's carpenter. The house's floor plan was common before 1740. It is a single house with no central hall. The bricDk for the front and south side of house are in the Flemish bond pattern. The other two sides are also brick in the English bond pattern.

properties.Name: Richard Edward Dereef House
properties.Description: 67 Alexander St. Richard Edward Dereef House. Dereef was a wood broker and real estate investor. the site was originally part of a large lot extending to Calhoun St. on which Dereef constructed several buildings. 67 Alexander is the only one left.

properties.Name: Simon Jude Chancognie House
properties.Description: 5 Alexander St. Simon Jude Chancognie House. Chancognie was a merchant and served as a French consul. The fire of 1838 missed the house. It remains one of the oldest houses in Mazyckborough,

properties.Name: Site of the Liberty Tree
properties.Description: 80 Alexander St. Site of the Liberty Tree. The tree was at the center of Mahzekborough. Christopher Gadsden and his party of “Mechanicks” began meeting at the tree in 1766. They later called themselves the “Sons of Liberty." The British cut down the tree in 1780. A "judge" named William Johnson allegedly made canes out of the tree's roots and sent one to Thomas Jefferson. The Liberty Tree is one of the sites where the Declaration of Independence was read to the public. It was read to the public twice at the Exchange Building.

properties.Name: Cordt Dieckhoff House
properties.Description: 126 Alexander St. Cordt Dieckhoff House. A house stood on the site in 1865. It was destroyed when a fire was started by an explosion that occurred at the Northeastern Rail Road Depot. Dieckhoff was a grocer from Germany. He bought the vacant lot in 1867 with a loan from the "Ordinance to aid in Rebuilding the Burnt Districts and Waste Places of the City." Charleston adopted the ordinance in 1866. He then constructed the building for tenants. Another tenement building was added to the rear of the lot in 1882.

properties.Name: The Memorial Missionary Baptist Church
properties.Description: 153 Alexander St. The Memorial Missionary Baptist Church was constructed c. 1886. Members of the First Baptist Church purchased the site for a burial ground in 1818. After the Civil War, the black members of First Baptist Church split to form the Memorial Missionary Baptist Church. In 1868, the First Baptist Church agreed to transfer 153 Alexander to Memorial Missionary Baptist Church.

properties.Name: Presqu’ile
properties.Description: 2 Amherst St. Presqu’ile (pronounced the same as in French "Presk-eel" meaning "almost an isle") was built by Jacob Belser from 1802-08. Interior includes an all-wood spiral staircase. It was originally on a point that went out into the Cooper River and was surrounded by marsh. In 1840, Henry Grimké, a brother to the Grimké sisters, bought the house. He added the square, 3-story wing (Greek Revival) at the rear.

properties.Name: Boyce - Storen House
properties.Description: 1 Ann St. Boyce - (Michael) Storen House. The house was built from 1847-1850. Storen was from Ireland's County Clare. He owned and operated a tannery at 900 King St. He purchased the house at 1 Ann as investment property. He lived at 3 Ann.

properties.Name: Michael Storen House
properties.Description: 3 Ann St. Michael Storen House. Storen was from Ireland's County Clare. He operated a tannery at 900 King St. He also owned 1 and 5 Ann St. as investment properties.

properties.Name: Camden and Tower Depots
properties.Description: 23-31 Ann St. Camden and Tower Depots. The depots were built for the South Carolina Railroad Company. Camden is possibly in reference to the Camden Branch of the South Carolina Railroad. The depots run the width of the block which the Charleston Area Regional Transit Authority (CARTA) uses as a bus terminal. CARTA's offices are at 36 John St. At 25 Ann St. is the Children's Museum of the Lowcountry. The Charleston Visitors Center is on the Ann Street end of the depots and uses the address 375 Meeting. "The Best Friend of Charleston," the first locomotive to pull a South Carolina Railroad train, is on display within the visitors center.

properties.Name: South Carolina Rail Road Company Freight Depot
properties.Description: 32-40 Ann St. South Carolina Rail Road Company Freight Depot. Cast iron keystones of each arch over the doorways contain a palmetto tree under the encircling initials "S.C.R.R." [S.C. Railroad] dated 1857. Curved roof line, brick pilasters, rose windows in the gable ends are similar in style and construction to the freight depot on John St. Currently the Music Farm & Charleston School of Law.

properties.Name: Goldsmith's Row
properties.Description: 11-25 Anson St. Goldsmith’s Row. The houses were developed by Isaac A. Goldsmith in 1894. He was a dentist, industrialist, and real estate investor. The seven houses were rental properties.

properties.Name: The Palmetto Fire Company Hall Building
properties.Description: 27 Anson St. The Palmetto Fire Company Hall Building. Volunteer firemen built it. The two windows in front on the bottom floor where the building's entrances.

properties.Name: Old Weils Mattress Factory
properties.Description: 28 Anson St. Old Weils Mattress Factory. George W. Williams first used the building as a cotton warehouse. A company called Robertson, Taylor and Company then owned the building to process cotton. Diminishing cotton production prompted the sale of the building to Weils Mattress Company. The company stayed in operation through 1970. There were multiple attempts to purchase and demolish the building until a developer was able to buy and convert the building into three townhouse condominiums.

properties.Name: 30 Anson St
properties.Description: Edward and Jane Johnson McCrady built the house. Jane gave the house to her eldest child, Edward McCrady (1833-1903). McCrady graduated from Yale, worked as an attorney, served as U.S. District Attorney for 11 years, and was elected to the S.C. legislature. He opposed the Nullification doctrine but signed off on the Ordinance of Secession. During the Civil War, he defended captured black soldiers. He also wrote The History of South Carolina in the Revolution, 1780-1783. McCrady sold the house in 1856.

properties.Name: Robert M. Venning House
properties.Description: 60 Anson St. Robert M. Venning House. The street-level floor once had entrances on Anson and Society and served as a residence and grocery for Claus Spreckels (1828-1908). He called his grocery business the “Egg Market.” Spreckles left Charleston before the Civil War and moved to California where he made an immense fortune processing and selling sugar.

properties.Name: Chazel House
properties.Description: 66 Anson St. (Elizabeth C.) Chazel House. Elizabeth was the wife of Jean Pierre Chazel. Slaves rebelled on Sainte-Domingue and forced the Chazel family to move to Charleston in 1794. Jean Pierre Chazal then became the captain of a small privateer called the Saucy Jack. During the War of 1812, Saucy Jack captured 40 British vessels. After the fire of 1838, records show that Elizabeth Chazel built the house that stands today. It is Philadelphia red brick with a Tuscan columned piazza on brick piers and a Greek Revival piazza door screen.

properties.Name: St. Stephen’s Episcopal
properties.Description: 67 Anson St. St. Stephen’s Episcopal was likely designed by John and Henry Horlbeck. They also owned the Boone Hall Plantation. St. Stephen's was the first "free church" in the U.S., i.e. rent was not required to sit in a pew.

properties.Name: The Thomas Doughty House
properties.Description: 71 Anson St. The Thomas Doughty (DOE-dee) House. The house is T-shaped to allow for more windows.

properties.Name: Joseph Legare House
properties.Description: 75 Anson St. Joseph Legare House. Legare owned land and grew crops along the Santee River. A third story was added in 1838 and then removed in 1974.

properties.Name: Legare-Mortimer House
properties.Description: 79 Anson St. (Daniel) Legare- (Edward) Mortimer House. Possibly the oldest house in Ansonborough.

properties.Name: The Mary Smith House
properties.Description: 82 Anson St. The Mary Smith House. Josiah Smith, a merchant, built the house for his daughter, Mary Smith. The original location of the house was 88 Anson. Mary Smith died in 1832. Mary Smith gave the house to her nieces and nephews. They then deeded the house to Mary Smith's sister, Ann Smith Tennent. She sold the house in 1869. The Historic Charleston Foundation bought the house in 1967 and moved it at the rate of 2ft/hr to make room for the Gaillard Center. The piazza came from Mary Smith's residence at 321 E Bay.

properties.Name: St. John’s Reformed Episcopal Church
properties.Description: 89-93 Anson St. The St. John’s Reformed Episcopal Church began as the Anson Street Chapel. In 1861, the chapel became the St. Joseph’s Roman Catholic Church. Its nickname was the “Church of the Irish.” The church was heavily damaged during the Civil War. It was almost completely re-built in 1883. The St. John’s Reformed Episcopal Church bought and restored the building in 1971. Philip Simmons (1912-2009) was a parishioner. He designed the gate (“Heart Gate”) for the garden. Pearl Fryar did the topiary.

properties.Name: Gage Hall
properties.Description: 4 Archdale St. Gage Hall. Alva Gage was a merchant. He constructed the building and gave it to the Unitarian Church. Below is an assembly room and above is living quarters for the church's minister.

properties.Name: Theodore Gaillard Jr. House
properties.Description: 96 Ashley Ave. Theodore Gaillard Jr. House. Gaillard was a commodities broker and crop grower. Note the fenestration on the front gable. Dr. Willis Wilkinson bought the house in 1825. He had two daughters who were both married to Christopher Gustavus Memminger (1803-1888). Memminger met the second daughter during a visit to the grave site of the first daughter. Memminger was born in Germany. His father was a soldier. He died one month after his son's birth. When Memminger was four years old, he and his mother immigrated to Charleston. Memminger was placed in an orphanage after his mother died of yellow fever not long after arriving in Charleston. At age 11, Memminger was adopted by Thomas Bennett. Memminger trained to be a lawyer. Memminger sided with the Confederacy during the Civil War and served as the Secretary of the Treasury. After the Civil War, Memminger spent much of his time building South Carolina's public school system.

properties.Name: Unitarian Universalist Church
properties.Description: 6 Archdale St. The Unitarian Universalist Church was built from 1772-87. Construction was halted during the Revolutionary War. The British used the uncompleted building for stabling. The church was originally the second meeting house for the Meeting House on Meeting Street. To maintain the church as one body, the church had two pastors who would alternate between the two pulpits and read the same sermon. The Gateway Walk was the path they used to walk back and forth between the meeting houses. The Archdale Meeting House split from the Meeting House in 1817 to become the Second Independent Church. The church was re-chartered in 1839 as the Unitarian Church of Charleston. The church was remodeled Perpendicular Gothic from 1852-1854.

properties.Name: St. John's Lutheran Church
properties.Description: 10 Archdale St. St. John's Lutheran Church. The church was completed in 1818. Abraham Reeves designed the ironwork. The church is known as the "Mother Church of Lutheranism" in S.C. John Bachman (1790 - 1874) served as pastor from 1815-1871. John James Audubon (1785 - 1851) met John Bachman during his first visit to Charleston in 1831. Audubon and Bachman built a strong friendship and worked closely together to complete Audubon's Birds of America and Vivaparous Quadrapeds. Audubon's two sons, John Woodhouse and Victor Gifford, married two of Bachman's daughters: Maria Rebecca and Mary Elizabeth, respectively. St. John's Lutheran was the first church to re-open after the Civil War. Ernest F. Hollings attended the church.

properties.Name: Philip Porcher House
properties.Description: 19 Archdale St. Philip Porcher House. The design changed to Regency in 1835. Porcher made substantial loans to South Carolina's government prior to the Revolutionary War. He became a Tory when the British occupied Charleston in 1780. Yet, Porcher was neither labeled a traitor nor lost his property to the U.S. government. He was judged as a "universal good character." The house has a magnificent garden that current resident Louisa Pringle Cameron and her husband tend. Cameron is also the author of numerous books about plants and gardens.

properties.Name: Bulwinkle - Ohlandt Building
properties.Description: 40 Archdale St. (John Henry) Bulwinkle - Ohlandt Building. The red brick was a popular building material after the Civil War. The top two floors are for residences. The bottom floor has been used for a variety of purposes, some not altogether legal. Bulwinkle first used the space for a grocery and a saloon. Once The Dispensary Act went into effect in 1893, the saloon turned into a spot where a person could receive for "free" a drink from the "blind tiger."

properties.Name: Baker Hospital
properties.Description: 55 Ashley Ave. (Dr. Archibald E. Sr.) Baker Hospital. Dr. Archibald Baker Sr. (1862-1934) and Dr. Lawrence R. Craig were the founders of the hospital in 1912. Baker became the sole owner of the hospital in 1916. Upon Baker's death, the hospital was re-commissioned as The Baker Memorial Sanatorium. Dr. Archibald Baker Jr. (1895-1951) managed the sanatorium until the end of World War II. The building was converted into condominiums in 1981.

properties.Name: John Hume Simmons House
properties.Description: 76 Ashley Ave. John Hume Simmons House. Simons was a rice grower. He gained ownership of the the lot at 76 Ashley by marrying his cousin, Mary Hume Lucas. Together, they had eight children. The double drawing rooms were large enough to perform the services for St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church while the city was getting bombarded during the Civil War. Mr. and Mrs. Emmet Robinson owned the house beginning in the 1960s. They were the founders of the Footlight Players. A portrait of the couple can be seen at the Dock Street Theatre.

properties.Name: William A. Courtenay House
properties.Description: 95 Ashley Ave. William A. Courtenay House. Courtenay served as the mayor from 1879-1887. It was during his administration that King and Meeting were paved for the first time.

properties.Name: 110 Ashley Ave.
properties.Description: 110 Ashley Ave. When William Thayer built this house in 1881, Ashley Ave. was called Lynch Street. Thayer purchased the lot from Francis J. Pelzer. The two-story frame dwelling is typical of Charleston’s late-19th century residential architecture. The house was built with an irregular plan as opposed to the traditional single and double houses of Charleston. Notice though the familiar weatherboard cladding, two-over-two wood sash windows (e.g., two panes of glass over two panes of glass), and a two-tiered piazza. The house gains its Italianate style through the low-pitched cross-hipped roof, the window crowns, the bracketed pediment over the entryway, the door itself, and later limited alterations.

properties.Name: Bennett - McElhenny House
properties.Description: 113 Ashley Ave. (Thomas Jr.) Bennett - (Susan) McElhenny House. The house sits on the only high point of land on Ashley Avenue. Bennett sold the house to Susan McElhenny in 1825. Bennett then moved to the house he built at 69 Barre. McElenny's daughter married Paul Hamilton Hayne. They had a son also named Paul Hamilton Hayne (1830 - 1886). Hayne was a lawyer and wrote for the News and Courier. He was also a friend of poet Henry Timrod (1828-1867). Hayne helped support Timrod and in 1872 published much of his writings, including "The Cotton Boll" and "Ode to the Confederate Dead at Magnolia Garden." A statue of Timrod stands at Washington Park.

properties.Name: U.S. Arsenal and Porter Military Academy Complex
properties.Description: 167-171 Ashley Ave. The U.S. Arsenal and Porter Military Academy Complex. Prior to the establishment of the complex, the site was a pauper's cemetery. The only buildings left are the Chapel (Gothic) and Colcock Hall (Greek Revival). They were completed in 1841. State militiamen seized it after secession. After the Civil War, Rev. A. Toomer Porter leased the site for $1 for 99 years to establish the Holy Communion Church Institute. It was later converted into the Porter Military Academy. Porter merged with Gaud School and Watt School in 1963 to become Porter-Gaud. MUSC then took over the property. The chapel was re-named St. Luke's, and Colcock Hall is now the MUSC President's Office.

properties.Name: Wickliffe House
properties.Description: 178 Ashley Ave. Wickliffe (John Hume Lucas) House. Lucas was a large land owner. Once Margaret Wickliffe became the owner of the house, she donated it to the Health Sciences Foundation of the Medical University of South Carolina. The university completed a restoration of the house in 1977. The building was used then used a faculty house. Today it is currently being leased for special events. There is also a tea room offering lunch daily.

properties.Name: Church of the Holy Communion
properties.Description: 218 Ashley Ave. Church of the Holy Communion (Episcopal). Rev. Nathaniel Bowen began forming the congregation of the Church of the Holy Communion in his home at 209 Ashley Ave. beginning in 1848. The commandant of the nearby Federal Arsenal attended one of his services and made available to Bowen space at the arsenal for services until a church building was completed at 218 Ashley in 1855. When Rev. A. Toomer Porter, the founder of the nearby Porter Military Academy in 1879, became the rector of the Church of the Holy Communion, he instituted the "high church" tradition.

properties.Name: Atlantic Street
properties.Description: Atlantic Street began as Lynch's Lane. It became Atlantic in 1837 to avoid confusion with Lynch Street.

properties.Name: The Benjamin Smith Houses
properties.Description: 1 and 3 Atlantic St. The Benjamin Smith Houses. Smith was a shipbuilder. Note the bays facing the street, a centered main entrance, no piazzas, and chimneys at the ends of the gable roof. 3 Atlantic was the home and studio of artist Elizabeth O’Neil Verner (1883-1979) from 1915-1937. Verner first studied under Alice Ravenel Huger Smith (1876-1958). Smith set her sights mostly on the Lowcountry, whereas Verner traveled widely. Verner's etchings appear in many museums and as the illustrations for Dubose Heyward's novel Porgy.

properties.Name: The Halsey House
properties.Description: 66 Barre St. The Halsey House was originally constructed c.1910 or earlier as the office of Halsey Lumber. Extensively restored in 2004 & 2005 back to it's more historic look, the restoration painstakingly removed the wainscoting piece by piece and removed years of paint. The kitchen was redesigned and custom fumed oak cabinets were installed along with soapstone from Vermont, a custom, hammered copper range hood from Archive Designs in OR, period tile and restoration glass accent the Arts & Craft style. Windows were pulled and restored to original, baseboards that were missing were cut from single piece heart pine pieces and installed. The original floors show almost no knots: the advantage of a lumber yard owner constructing the building. Hand painted stencil in the bedroom, on mantles and Wm. Morris wallpaper, and period lighting and some custom lighting accent the Arts & Crafts style. The third room has been used as a bedroom but it is very small. Very high ceilings, lots of natural light and 4 gas fireplaces and a water pressure pump. It has been used as a nursery or an office in the past. The oak tree in the back yard may be one of, if not the, largest oak tree on the peninsula. The small garden house does NOT convey with the property and will be removed prior to closing. Home featured in Charleston Home magazine and HGTV's Generation Renovation in 2005.

properties.Name: Thomas Bennett Jr. House
properties.Description: 69 Barre St. Thomas Bennett Jr. House. Bennett built the house on land inherited from his father, Thomas Bennett, Sr. (1754 - 1814). Thomas Bennett Sr. and Daniel Cannon used the land and surrounding water to operate a lumber mill. In addition to many other political offices, Thomas Bennett Jr. served as the governor of South Carolina from 1820-1822. The house is now owned by The Roper Foundation.

properties.Name: William Cunningham House
properties.Description: 5 Bedons Alley. William Cunningham House. Cunningham emigrated to South Carolina from Scotland. He owned land and grew crops close to where Magnolia Cemetery and St Lawrence Cemetery are today. It was a single-house that was two bays wide. George Whitfield bought the house in 1794 and added the three-story brick wing on the south side. William Doran became the owner in 1857. Doran was a stevedore. His house withstood Federal bombardment better than most. He took in many refugees during the Civil War. Although the house did not prevent a cannon ball from taking off one of Doran's arms. It happened while he was reaching for a match on his fireplace mantel to light a guest's pipe. He then became known as "Generous old William, ask for a light and he gives you his arm."

properties.Name: 2 Bedons Alley
properties.Description: Humphrey Sommers constructed the house after the fire of 1778. Sommers was also the mason for St. Michael's Church.

properties.Name: Bedons Alley
properties.Description: Pronounced "BEE-don’s." The street appeared on the Crisp Map (1704) but without a name. The "Ichnography of 1739" labels it Middle Lane. Deeds going as far back as 1733 give the street the name Beadon's or Bedon's Street or Alley. The name refers to George Beadon (Bedon). He owned a store and land on the street.

properties.Name: Bee Street
properties.Description: Named after Thomas Bee (1739 - 1812). He was a delegate to the Second Continental Congress, Lieutenant Governor of South Carolina and a U.S. District Judge. He lived at 94 Church. Bee Street was one of the original streets of Cannonborough.

properties.Name: Wiliam Robb House
properties.Description: 12 Bee St. Wiliam Robb House. Robb grew and milled rice. In 1920, the proerty was purchased by Mercy Maternity Hospital. Mercy was the first maternity ward in Charleston. The property was given to the Church Home and Orphanage Corporation in 1927. Two years later, it became the Episcopal Church Home for Women. The house has been an apartment building since 1984.

properties.Name: Blake Street
properties.Description: Named for Joseph Blake (1663-1700). Blake was a governor of South Carolina in 1694 and from 1696 until his death in 1700. His uncle was John Archdale. Famous iron worker Philip Simmons lived and worked on Blake Street.

properties.Name: Philip Simmons House
properties.Description: 30 Blake St. Philip Simmons’ house and workshop. Simmons was born in 1912 on Daniel Island. He began apprenticing as a blacksmith in Charleston at age eight. He originally made carriage wheels. As cars began replacing carriages, Simmons turned to ornamental ironwork. In 1976, Simmons was invited to the Smithsonian Institute to demonstrate his ironwork techniques. In 2007, the workshop was listed on the 11 most Endangered Properties in America.

properties.Name: Broad Street
properties.Description: According to the Grand Modell, Broad Street was Cooper St. It was named in honor of Anthony Ashley-Cooper, a Lord Proprietor. Town people though favored calling it Broad Street because of its unusual width. Starting on the east end (Broad and East Bay), the street was 61 feet wide. It then widened to 100 feet by the time it reached St. Michael's Church and the Beef Market (present-day Four Corners of Law). Cooper and Broad were interchangeable until Broad won out in 1714. Prior to the Civil War, considerable slave trade occurred on Broad Street between Church and East Bay. William Payne & Sons was likely the busiest auction house in the Lowcountry between 1803 and 1834. The business sometimes acted as agent for the City Sheriff to collect court-ordered debts. Payne brokered the sale of more than 9,200 local enslaved people. While many were enslaved in town, many more worked in the surrounding countryside on plantations. Small private sales and large auctions took place both in the city and wherever the enslaved lived.

properties.Name: Walker, Evans & Cogswell Building
properties.Description: 3 Broad St. (John C.) Walker, (Benjamin F.) Evans, & (Harvey) Cogswell Building. Built for Edward Debring, president of the State Bank next door. In 1856, it was bought by Walker, Evans, & Cogwell. They connected the building to their printing business at 117 East Bay. The company printed the minutes and other documents of the Secession Convention and printed currency, bonds, stamps, etc. for the Confederacy. General Sherman set fire to the business when the company moved to Columbia during the Civil War.The business was re-established in 1867 at Meeting and Market and then 3 Broad where it remained in operation until 1982.

properties.Name: S.G. Courtenay & Co. Bookstore Building
properties.Description: 11 Broad St. S.G. Courtenay & Co. Bookstore Building. Author William Gilmore Simms (1806 - 1870) is known for doing much of his writing on the bookstore's counters. In 1912, E. H. Robertson Cigar Co. began operating its business in the building. In 1941, it became Robertson's Cafeteria and was a popular gathering place for the town's political and business leaders.

properties.Name: The Second Bank of the United States
properties.Description: 16 Broad St. The Second Bank of the United States. The First Bank of the United States lost its charter in 1811. The charter for the Second Bank was drawn up by John C. Calhoun. Andrew Jackson withdrew the U.S. government's deposits in 1833 due to mismanagement. The Second Bank collapsed one year later. A group of South Carolina investors then organized the Bank of Charleston. The bank almost failed after loaning the Confederacy $1.5 million. In 1926, the Bank of Charleston merged with the Norwood National Bank of Greenville and Carolina National Bank of Columbia to become the South Carolina National Bank. The gilded oak eagle located in the pediment was made in 1817.

properties.Name: The People's Building
properties.Description: 18 Broad St. The People’s Building was completed in 1911 as Charleston’s first “skyscraper." The cost of the building was $300,000. The first two floors are faced with Winnsboro granite. Upper floors are yellow-buff brick and terra cotta. Development was led by R. Goodwyn Rhett, mayor and president of the People's National Bank. An easement restricts the first four floors to office and retail. The top floor and rooftop are all one unit with 72 windows that allows a 360-degree view of the harbor and peninsula.

properties.Name: The McDowell Building
properties.Description: 36-38 Broad St. Bank of the State of South Carolina. 36 and 38 Broad are now one of Charleston's most popular night spots. It is called The Blind Tiger. Charleston was earning enormous revenue on the tax of alcohol. Governor Tillman and the rest of South Carolina believed the wealth should be not so concentrated. Once The Dispensary Act went into effect in 1893, to purchase alcohol anywhere than from the state was known as a "blind tiger."

properties.Name: Benjamin Smith House
properties.Description: 49 Broad St. Benjamin Smith House. Smith was a merchant. The balcony with the "For Sale" sign covering it is considered one of the best examples of 18th century ironwork in Charleston.

properties.Name: West Street
properties.Description: West Street. The street is named after Joseph West. He led the English settlers to the Carolina province and served as the royal governor three times. It is not known when he was born. He died in 1691. The exact day is not known.

properties.Name: Bank of South Carolina
properties.Description: 50 Broad St. Bank of South Carolina. The bank was chartered in 1801. In 1802, a man from Kentucky named William Withers attempted to rob the bank. Withers was a horse trader. After Withers lost his horses and a lot more in cards, he came up with the idea of robbing the Bank of South Carolina to settle his debts. To get to the bank's money, Withers spent three months digging a tunnel. He started from an arched drain on the east side of Church St. and spent the next three months digging towards the bank's own underground tunnel. While Withers stayed underground, he would "pop up" from the arched drain to receive food and supplies from his accomplice. The accomplice's suspicious trips to the arched drain was noticed and reported. Withers was pulled from the drainage line and arrested on Oct. 8, 1803. Newspaper reports labeled Withers the "ground mole." When he was tried, the judge confirmed with Withers that he lived in the street drain for three months. The judge then ruled, "Release that man, he has suffered enough." Withers is today known as the "wack-a-mole ghost."

properties.Name: Clark Mills Studio
properties.Description: 51-53 Broad St. Clark Mills Studio. Built by Benjamin Smith. Sculptor Clark Mills (1815-1883) used the building for a studio. He is best known for the bust of John C. Calhoun in City Hall, the statue of Andrew Jackson in Lafayette Square in Washington, DC, and "Freedom" in the dome of the U.S. Capitol.

properties.Name: 56-58 Broad St
properties.Description: 56-58 Broad St. In 1869, the building was the site of the National Freedman's Savings Bank. After five years of fraud and mismanagement, the bank closed. John Geddes (1777-1828) constructed and was the first to own the building. He was an attorney and active Republican. From 1818-1820, he was the Governor of South Carolina. While serving as governor, he hosted U.S. President James Monroe during his visit to Charleston in 1819. In 1823, Geddes ran for Intendant (present-day Mayor) of Charleston against Edward P. Simons. The mud slinging was offensive enough for Geddes' son to challenge Simons to a duel. Simons was able to fire off four shots, two of which hit Geddes in the thighs. The shots that Geddes' son fired killed Simons. Permitting your son to shoot and kill your opponent is one way of improving one's chances of winning an election.

properties.Name: The Confederate Home
properties.Description: 60-64 Broad St. The Confederate Home. Built by Gilbert Chalmers. Chalmers' daughter was the wife of John Geddes, South Carolina's governor from 1818-1820. Geddes and his wife hosted President James Monroe at the Confederate House in 1819. Angus Stewart bought the house in 1834 and turned it into the Carolina Hotel. Archibald McKenzie later operated the Carolina Hotel. He then rented the building in 1867 to the Home for the Mothers, Widows, and Daughters of Confederate Soldiers. The building continues to serve as apartments for elderly women.

properties.Name: Schachte Building
properties.Description: 71 Broad St. Schachte Building. Prior to the Schachte Building, it was the Mansion House Hotel. The Mansion House was built in 1772. Jehu Jones Sr. bought his freedom in 1798. He bought the hotel that was operating at 71 Broad in 1815 and re-named the hotel Jones Hotel. It was written, "Every Englishman who visits Charleston, will, if he be wise, direct his baggage to Jones's hotel." Among the guests were Samuel F.B. Morse, architect William Jay, and actress Fanny Kemble. Jones died in 1833. Jones's son, Edward, attended Amherst and was the first black to graduate from the school. Jane Davis bought the hotel in 1852 and operated it as the Mansion House. The hotel began to fall in disrepair after the Civil War and was demolished in 1928. The Schachte Building was constructed in 1930. It is now the parish office for St. Michael's.

properties.Name: Charleston City Hall
properties.Description: 80-82 Broad St. Charleston City Hall. Prior to the construction of the building, the site was a beef market. A fire destroyed the beef market in 1796. In 1800, the City Council conveyed the land to the First Bank of the United States which was located at 100 Church. The construction of the building was finished in 1804. After the bank's charter expired in 1811, the property was conveyed back to the city. The city began using the building as the City Hall in 1818.

properties.Name: Wentworth Street
properties.Description: Wentworth Street. Named for Charles Watson-Wentworth (1730-1782). Also the Marquess of Rockingham. When serving as England's prime minister, he introduced legislation to repeal the Stamp Act in early 1766.

properties.Name: Centenary Methodist
properties.Description: 60 Wentworth. Centenary Methodist. White Edward Brickell wanted the doors between the columns but was overruled. He argued their placement is “in violation of architectural propriety and good taste.”

properties.Name: Old South Carolina Statehouse and Charleston County Courthouse
properties.Description: 84 Broad St. Old South Carolina Statehouse and Charleston County Courthouse. Charleston County Courthouse. NW corner of the Four Corners of Law. The Statehouse for the royal colony of South Carolina was completed in 1758. When the colonies declared their independence from the England's royal crown, the building became the site for the public reading of the Declaration of Independence. After the Revolutionary War, the State House became the state capitol from 1783-1786. Columbia was then declared the state capital. In 1788, Charleston's State House burned. It was re-built in close likeness to the previous building, except for a third floor that was added. The building is currently the property of the Charleston County government.

properties.Name: Josiah Smith Tenement
properties.Description: 85-87 Broad St. Josiah Smith Tenement. Smith built the tenements for his sons William Stevens Smith and Samuel Smith, respectively. They have since became incorporated into Charleston's U.S. Federal District Court.

properties.Name: Hebrew Orphanage
properties.Description: 88 Broad St. Hebrew Orphanage. William Trescott built and rented the building to the Bank of the State of South Carolina. The bank moved to 19 Broad St. in 1817. The Hebrew Orphan Society bought the building in 1833. The society was founded in 1801. It is the oldest incorporated Jewish charitable organization in the United States. The society has 36 members. The word for "eighteen" in Hebrew is "chai." The word also means "life" in Hebrew. Therefore the number of members represents double chai.

properties.Name: David Ramsay House
properties.Description: 92 Broad St. David Ramsay House. Ramsay (1749-1815) bought the house in 1783. He was married to Martha Laurens. Ramsay served in the General Assembly from 1776-1781. When the city fell to England in 1780, Ramsay was exiled to St. Augustine. He was also a doctor and a writer. He was the author of a number of historical works, including Ramsay’s History of South Carolina, From Its First Settlement 1670 to 1808. He also wrote A Dissertation on the Manners of Acquiring the Character and Privileges of a Citizen. One of his patients shot him 1815. He is buried at the Circular Congregational Church.

properties.Name: Faculty Offices
properties.Description: 88 Wentworth. Riggs Tenements. John S. Riggs developed the town’s first street car system in 1866. Potholes in the streets sometimes reveal iron rails.

properties.Name: Bocquet House
properties.Description: 93 Broad St. (Peter Jr.) Bocquet House. Peter Bocquet Sr. purchased the lot in 1749. He was a baker from France. The house was built by Bocquet's son, Peter Jr., who was a wealthy land owner and traded deerskins. State congressman and military leader James Simons and his son, James Jr., owned the house from the mid 1850's to 1925. The house then slowly fell into disrepair. In 2009, Meadors Construction completed the restoration of the building.

properties.Name: Meyer-Peace House
properties.Description: 96 Broad St. (Philip) Meyer- (Joseph) Peace House. The building originally stood at 8 Courthouse Square and was used for refining sugar. It was moved 185 ft. at the rate of 1ft/minute to Broad St. in the late 1990s to make room for the construction of the Charleston County Judicial Center at 100 Broad.

properties.Name: Grace Episcopal Church
properties.Description: 100 Wentworth. Grace Episcopal Church. The church's rector after the end of the Civil War was Dr. Charles Cotesworth Pinckney (1855-1898). When Federal authorities instructed Pinckney that his service prayers had to include the President of the United States, he acquiesced with "I know of no one who needs praying for more than the President of the United States." The columbarium and bell tower were completed in 1999.

properties.Name: Henry Frost Surgery
properties.Description: 98 Broad St. Dr. Henry Frost Surgery. In 1752, Dr. Alexander Garden also likely lived at this location. Garden inoculated 2,000 people against smallpox in 1760. Carl Linnaeus named Gardenia jasminoides after Alexander Garden. Garden called the Southern magnolia “the finest and most superb evergreen tree that the earth produced.” He also wrote an essay about the medicinal qualities of Indian pink or pinkroot (Spigelia marilandica). Garden was a Tory and had to leave Charleston/Charlestowne in 1782. The outbuilding that Garden lived in and much of the back of the existing building were demolished to make room for the county building. Since 1984, 98 Broad has been a French café called Gaulart & Maliclet. Some like to call it "Fast and French."

properties.Name: Charleston County Judicial Center
properties.Description: 84 Broad St. Charleston County Judicial Center. The square in front of the building is called Court House Square. It began as the State House Square when the S.C. State House was located at the site. The capital of South Carolina was moved to Columbia after the Revolutionary War. The building that was the State House burned in 1788. The new building at 84 Broad resembles closely the State House and currently serves as the Charleston County Courthouse, thus the new name for the square. The statue of William Pitt that once stood at the intersection of Broad St. and Meeting St. is now located in the entrance hall of the Charleston County Judicial Center.

properties.Name: Edwin L. Kerrison House
properties.Description: 138 Wentworth. Edwin L. Kerrison House. The columns are referred to as Tower of the Winds. Water from the cistern was piped to various buildings, thus an early form of plumbing in Charleston. From 1947-1970, the house was the main office for the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of South Carolina. Since 1970 it has been a private residence. Philip Simmons forged the driveway gates.

properties.Name: John Lining House
properties.Description: 106 Broad St. John Lining House. Maybe the oldest frame structure in the city. John Lining (1708-1760) was from Scotland. Part of Lining’s work was to use scientific instruments to record weather data in North America. Lining had considerable correspondence with Benjamin Franklin. Lining also wrote the first account of the outbreak of yellow fever in North America. Later, the house was the residence of Andrew Turnbull and his wife Maria Gracia after they abandoned their colony in New Smyrna in 1781. Maria Gracia Turnbull was the first known Greek resident of Charleston. She is buried at St. Michael's Church.

properties.Name: Thomas Pinckney Jr. House
properties.Description: 114 Broad St. Col. Thomas Pinckney Jr. House. Pinckney was the son of Gen. Thomas Pinckney (1750 - 1828). Gen. Thomas Pinckney was the son of Charles Pinckney (1699-1758) and Eliza Lucas (1722 - 1793). Gen. Thomas Pinckney's brother was Charles Cotesworth Pinckney (1746 - 1825). Edward Rutledge's and Charles Cotesworth Pinckney were law partners. The former signed the Declaration of Independence, the latter the U.S. Constitution. Pinckney also figured prominently in the XYZ Affair. From Aug. - Dec. 1863, Gen. P.G.T. Beauregard used the house for his headquarters. Note the portico with four columns atop an arcaded base with curving steps on either side.

properties.Name: The John Rutledge House
properties.Description: 116 Broad St. The John Rutledge House. John Rutledge (1739 - June 21, 1800) built the house in 1763 for his wife, Elizabeth Grimké (1742-1792). Elizabeth was the daughter of Frederick Grimké (1705-1778). Frederick was the uncle of John Faucheraud Grimké. Elizabeth and the father of the Grimké sisters, John Faucheraud Grimké, were cousins. Christopher Werner did the iron work in 1853 at the behest of Thomas Norman Gadsden. When Arthur Barnwell owned the house, it took eight years to install the wood floors he wanted. After the Declaration of Independence was signed, South Carolina put in place its own constitution with Rutledge serving as President and "dictator." Rutledge was then elected the governor of South Carolina in 1779. Rutledge remained in office until 1782 and then became a judge. Rutledge signed the Constitution of the U.S. in 1789 and was then named to the U.S. Supreme Court in 1790. He was named Chief Justice of the United States on August 12, 1795. Declining mental health allowed Rutledge to hold the position for only a few months. The building currently operates as a luxury inn with 19 guest rooms.

properties.Name: Wentworth Mansion
properties.Description: 149 Wentworth. Francis Silas Rogers House. Completed in 1887. Rogers was a cotton trader, operated phosphate mines, and was in the shipping business. He was also chairman of the Board of Firemasters. He watched for fires from the house’s cupola. The interior is elaborately finished in mahogany, oak, and walnut. There are also tile floors, ornate plasterwork, hand-carved marble fireplaces and mantels, Tiffany stained glass windows, and crystal chandeliers. It is excess beyond imagination! The house is operated as a hotel today. The carriage house is now a highly rated restaurant called "Circa 1886."

properties.Name: Edward Rutledge House
properties.Description: 117 Broad St. Edward Rutledge House. Built by James Laurens. Edward Rutledge (1749-1800) bought the house in 1788. Rutledge's law partner was Charles Cotesworth Pinckney. Rutledge and Pinckney signed the Declaration of Independence and U.S. Constitution, respectively. He was the governor of South Carolina from 1798 until his death on January 23, 1800. Rutledge is buried at St. Philip's. It is written on Rutledge's headstone that he was the governor of South Carolina but not a signer of the Declaration of Independence. The house currently operates as an inn.

properties.Name: St. Andrew's Hall
properties.Description: 118 Broad St. St. Andrew's Hall. The St. Andrew's Hall was built from 1814-1815. It was accessible only to the town's most upper crust. On Nov. 6, 1860, Abraham Lincoln was elected President of the United States. With slavery in jeopardy, South Carolina delegates met to discuss secession from the Union at St. Andrew's Hall on Dec. 19, 1860. The next day they gathered at the South Carolina Institute Hall and voted to become the first state to leave the Union. The count was in favor 160-0! The fire that raced through the town one year later destroyed the building along with the South Carolina Institute Hall.

properties.Name: Fleming - (Mary Jane) Ross House.
properties.Description: 144 Wentworth. Fleming - (Mary Jane) Ross House. Mary Jane Ross was a descendent of the Flemings. In 1922, Ross placed the house in a trust as a memorial to the services of women in Charleston during World War I and to those who were victims of an influenza epidemic in Charleston in 1918. The red cross on the wall of Smith Street side of the property indicates that the house was for many years an office for the American Red Cross.

properties.Name: Morton Waring House
properties.Description: 119 Broad St. Morton Waring House. Waring broke up the property into three lots and sold them after the Embargo Act of 1807 crushed his accounting business. The buyer of the lot with the house standing today at 119 Broad was Moses Mordecai Cohen (1804-1888). Cohen rivaled James Adger as the wealthiest person in South Carolina. When the Marquis de Lafayette visited Charleston in 1825, it was Cohen's gold plates that were used for the dinner parties. Much of Cohen's fortune was tied up in real estate that was lost in the fire of 1838. It was a later owner who added the marble front to the house. The current owner is musician Darius Rucker.

properties.Name: The Cathedral of St. John the Baptist
properties.Description: 122 Broad St. The Cathedral of St. John the Baptist. Construction ended in 1907. CT brownstone with star-shaped indentations. The steeple wasn’t added until 2010. For 100 years, it was the only Catholic Cathedral in the U.S. without a steeple.

properties.Name: McCully Righton House
properties.Description: 11 Water St. McCully Righton House. The first house built on Water St. The address at some point was changed to 44 Church.

properties.Name: Charles Robert Vaulk House
properties.Description: 125 Broad St. Charles Robert Vaulk House. Valk owned a part of Valk and Murdock. The company was involved in machine and iron work and built ships. It grew to become known as the Charleston Shipbuilding and Drydock Co. Valk started building his house after the earthquake of 1886. He constructed it to be earthquake-proof. Iron rods run the length of the chimneys. A new hazard was created when the iron shingles were replaced by asbestos shingles in the 1960s.

properties.Name: The Cooper-O'Connor House
properties.Description: 180 Broad St. The Cooper-O'Connor House. The Confederates made the house a prison for Union officers to expose them to the Union's bombardment of the city. President Lincoln countered by exposing 600 Confederate prisoners to the Confederate's bombardment of Morris Island that was under the control of the Union. The Union artillery leveled practically every building around the house.

properties.Name: Water Street
properties.Description: Water Street was Vanderhorst Creek before it was a street. England's last royal governor, William Campbell, fled Charlestown via Vanderhorst Creek to reach HRM Tamar to escape the escalating violence in Charlestown. There are mooring posts at the intersection of Church and Water. Campbell's rowboat was likely tied to one of those mooring posts!

properties.Name: Tobias Scott House
properties.Description: 17 Water St. Tobias Scott House. Scott made fans out of turkey feathers. The Charleston Museum has two of his fans in its collection. Recent construction work at the location revealed large numbers of turkey bones in the backyard. Scott earned sufficient income from his trade to send his children to college. They were a part of the first generation of post-Civil War black children to receive higher education.

properties.Name: Vanderhorst Street
properties.Description: Vanderhorst Street. Pronounced "van-DROSS”? Named for Arnoldus Vanderhorst (1748-1815). The first documented date for the street is 1793. Vanderhorst also had a creek named after him. It is now Water Street. The plantation Vanderhorst owned was what is now much of Kiawah Island. Vanderhorst gained ownership of his plantation through his wife. John Stanyarne. He bought the land in 1737 from William Davis and the reputed pirate, William Raynor. He raised cattle and grew indigo on the land. At the time of his death in 1772, his will divided the island between his two granddaughters: Mary Gibbs received the western half, and Elizabeth Vanderhorst the east. The house that the Vanderhorsts built to live in was destroyed by the British in 1780 during the American Revolution. The plantation house was rebuilt in 1801.

properties.Name: Irish Volunteers Armory
properties.Description: 12 Vanderhorst. Irish Volunteers Armory. The Irish Volunteers were a militia unit that was organized in 1798. The formation of militia units has been largely replaced by the National Guard.

properties.Name: McCrady's Tavern
properties.Description: 2 Unity Alley. McCrady's (second) Tavern. McCrady was imprisoned at St. Augustine during the Revolutionary War. Upon his return to Charleston, he moved his tavern business from 153 Meeting to 2 Unity Alley. It is at Unity Alley in 1791 that a dinner was given for George Washington in the tavern's "Long Room." The building still operates as a drinking and dining establishment.

properties.Name: Tradd Street
properties.Description: Tradd Street. Tradd is the oldest street in Charleston. It was named after Robert Tradd, or possibly his son, also named Robert. The son was the first child of European descent born in the province. The street might have more pre-18th century homes than any street in the U.S. Boats could once be pulled up to 172 Tradd. Either Broad between Meeting and Bay or the western end of Tradd was "the usual place" where slaves were bought and sold.

properties.Name: Lamboll’s Tenements
properties.Description: 8-10 Tradd. Lamboll’s Tenements. Judge Thomas Lamboll lived at 19 King. Note the gambrel or "Dutch gable" roof. While it was used elsewhere in Charlestowne, few others are seen today. The building fell into disrepair and was restored by Susan Pringle Frost.

properties.Name: Hext Tenements
properties.Description: 51 Tradd. Hext Tenements. Col. Alexander Hext owned a plantation on Johns Island and was a crop grower. George Saxby also resided at this location. He was serving as King George III's Inspector of Stamp Duties when the Stamp Act was passed in 1765. Part of the widespread resistance to the act was a mob ransacking Saxby's house to destroy the stamps and burning Hext in effigy.

properties.Name: John Stuart House
properties.Description: 106 Tradd. Col. John Stuart House. Completed in 1772. Notice “hipped” roof. William Bartram (1739-1823) arrived in Charlestowne on March 31, 1773. He learned that a meeting among indigenous people was to take place in Augusta, Georgia, in June. The Superintendent of Indian affairs, John Stuart, invited Bartram to accompany him to the meeting. From Augusta, Bartram was able to arrange to travel to Florida where he explored and lived for two years. Bartram relates in a book about his travels an incident in 1776 in South Georgia where he encounters an "intrepid Siminole" who had resolved upon killing the next white man he met but was disarmed by Bartram's unexpected friendliness.

properties.Name: Peter Fayssoux House
properties.Description: 126 Tradd. Dr. Peter Fayssoux House. Note the exposed interior corner-posts. They can also be seen at The Lining House, 106 Broad St. Fayssoux was the surgeon-general in the Continental Army during the Revolutionary War. Fayssoux had two grandsons who were Confederate generals. Of the two, Bernard Elliott Bee was the one who gave Gen. Thomas J. Jackson the nickname "Stonewall." Also the home of poet Beatrice Witte Ravenel.

properties.Name: Winthrop House
properties.Description: 129 Tradd St. (Joseph) Winthrop House. Winthrop was a merchant from Massachusetts. His wife owned the land on which the house is built. The house has also been the residence of Samuel Gaillard Stoney and Robert Jordan. Stoney was a historian and an author. Jordan wrote the fantasy novel The Wheel of Time under the pseudonym James Oliver Rigney Jr. His wife, Harriet McDougal, was Jordan's editor. Amazon Prime produced a movie version of The Wheel of Time in the fall of 2021.

properties.Name: Ruth Lowndes Simmons House
properties.Description: 131 Tradd St. Ruth Lowndes Simmons House. Francis Simmons purchased the house at 131 Tradd for his wife, Ruth Lowndes, after they were married. Ruth Lowndes Simmons then lived at 131 Tradd while Francis Simmons resided at 14 Legare. Supposedly they never spent a night under the same roof together.

properties.Name: U.S. Coast Guard
properties.Description: 200 Tradd St. Chisolm's Mill. In 1939, the site became U.S. Coast Guard base.

properties.Name: Chisolm-Alston House.
properties.Description: 172 Tradd. (Alexander Hext) Chisolm - (William Algernon) Alston House. The house was completed in 1836. Chisolm owned and operated Chisolm's Mill. Chisolm Street is also named after him. The mill was located where the Coast Guard is currently stationed. Chisolm sold the house to Alston in 1855.

properties.Name: Thomas Barksdale House
properties.Description: 1 Tradd St. Thomas Barksdale House. Robert Wells also owned the house. Wells and G. Bruce founded The South-Carolina Weekly Gazette in 1758. In 1764, the name was changed to the The South-Carolina and American General Gazette. Of the three loyalist newspapers in Charlestowne, Wells' paper was the only one to support the The Stamp Act. It was also the only paper in the colony to publish in its entirety the Declaration of Independence. During the time the British occupied Charlestowne from 1781-1738, the name of the paper was The Royal Gazette. The building has also served as an auto repair shop.

properties.Name: Alicia Rhett House
properties.Description: 59 Tradd. Alicia Rhett House. Mary Alicia Rhett (1915-2014) was a graduate of the Memminger High School. She became a portrait painter, an actress, and radio announcer for Charleston's WTMA. She is best known for her role as India Wilkes in the movie Gone With the Wind (1939).

properties.Name: Bull Street
properties.Description: Named after William Bull (1683-1755). Bull was a son of Stephen Bull. Stephen Bull was a deputy of Lord Ashley and was aboard the Carolina when it reached the Carolina coast in 1670. The site is known today as Bulls Island. His son, William, served under John Barnwell in the Tuscarora War in 1712. He fought in the Yamasee War from 1712-1715. In 1720, he became the first royal lieutenant governor of the Carolina province. He worked closely with Charles Pinckney and the General Assembly to work out European settlers' legal claims to land. He was also the first to find out about slaves organizing the Stono Rebellion in 1739. He lived at 35 Meeting St. A monument to William Bull stands at the Ashley Hall Plantation.

properties.Name: Cameron House
properties.Description: 12 Bull St. Hugh P. Cameron House. Cameron was a crockery merchant. The house has two front parlors, a small room, and stair hall in the rear with an entrance in a pavilion on the east side. Currently the Caroline and Albert Simons Jr. Center for Historic Preservation.

properties.Name: William Blacklock House
properties.Description: 18 Bull St. William Blacklock House. One of the nation's most important Federal houses. Although the outbuildings are Gothic Revival. The bricks are 18" thick and laid in Flemish bond. Blacklock was on the building committee for City Hall. It became the property of the C of C in 1971 through a gift from Richard H. Jenrette.

properties.Name: Holy Trinity Reformed Episcopal Church
properties.Description: 51 Bull St. Holy Trinity Reformed Episcopal Church. In 1874, a group of black members left the Protestant Episcopal Church and were admitted into the Reformed Episcopal Church. Together they became the Holy Trinity Reformed Episcopal Church. They purchased 51 Bull Street in 1876 and built the church in 1880. It was completed in three weeks at a cost of $1,000. Welling & Gleason were the contractors.

properties.Name: Denmark Vesey’s home
properties.Description: 56 Bull St. Denmark Vesey’s home. On July 15, 1818, Reverend Morris Brown (1770-1849), other African- American ministers and laymen, and about 1,000 of their followers seceded from the Methodist Church and became affiliated with Reverend Allen’s A.M.E. movement in Philadelphia. Morris Brown, et al, organized several meeting houses and then built a church in the Hampstead suburb of Charleston at Reid and Hanover Streets. Among Brown’s followers was Denmark Vesey (c. 1767-1822). He and his master, Captain Joseph Vesey, relocated to Charleston in the late 1790s. Vesey had traveled extensively and was multilingual. In 1799, he won $1500 from a local lottery, purchased his freedom, and established a carpentry business. In 1822, Denmark Vesey and members of the Hampstead Church attempted an uprising in Charleston and an escape to Haiti. The uprising was planned for July 14 (Bastille Day). When the day came, there was no storming of Charleston’s streets and buildings. Peter Prioleau, a house slave of Colonel John C. Prioleau, informed his master that he had learned about Vesey’s plot from another slave. Col. Prioleau then raised then alerted the city's intendant (mayor) James Hamilton Jr. Hamilton organized a patrol for the town’s streets and a search for the perpetrators. 131 men were arrested of which 117 were charged with various crimes. 38 were released for lack of evidence. Twenty of the 79 who were tried were acquitted. Eleven of the men acquitted were determined to be so dangerous that they were expelled from the state of South Carolina. Between 6 and 8 a.m. on July 2, 1822, Denmark Vesey and five of his co-conspirators were hanged. By year’s end, another 29 were hanged. The rest, including Vesey’s son, were exiled to Spanish Cuba.

properties.Name: Huchet House
properties.Description: 84 Bull St. Huchet House. Count Eugene Joseph Huchet bought the house in 1857. His fortune was supposedly wiped out in a single day of cotton trading. He was able to leave his house to his three daughters. The longest surviving daughter was Naomi Elizabeth Huchet. She bequeathed the house as a home for elderly woman. Hurricane Hugo took off the front piazza with Doric columns on the first level and Ionic columns on the second.

properties.Name: John Fabre Jr. House
properties.Description: 6 Tradd St. John Fabre Jr. House. The house was built on lot #7 of the "Grand Modell." John Fabre purchased the house after it was built. It had any number of other owners and uses until Susan Pringle Frost purchased the property along with others close by to prevent their demolition.

properties.Name: Francis Warrington Dawson House
properties.Description: 99 Bull St. Francis Warrington Dawson House. Dawson lived from 1840-1889. He emigrated from England in 1862 aboard a Confederate cruiser. He fought in eleven battles for the Confederates and was wounded three times before he was made a prisoner. After the Civil War, Dawson worked in Richmond and then moved to Charleston. In 1866, he went to work for the Charleston Mercury. One year later, Bartholomew Rochelot Riordan and Dawson bought an interest in the Charleston News. In April 1873, Riordan and Dawson were able to acquire the Charleston Courier. They combined the two papers into the News and Courier with Dawson as the editor. Dawson promoted "fusion" during Reconstruction. He used the term to encourage white voters to help elect worthy Republicans rather than boycott the polls. In 1888, Pope Leo XIII knighted Dawson to the Order of St. Gregory for his editorials against dueling. Dawson also wrote in fierce opposition to lynching. On March 12, 1889, Dawson entered the office of Dr. Thomas B. McDow. Rather than cure Dawson, McDow shot Dawson twice and killed him after accusing him of making "dishonorable advances" towards the governess of his children. McDow was acquitted of murder on the claim of self-defense. The basement today is a dentist's office.

properties.Name: Bee's Row
properties.Description: 101-109 Bull St. Bee's Row. The row of houses were built originally for Sarah Smith in the 1850s. She lived at 101 Bull. William C. Bee acquired the buildings during the Civil War. He used the buildings for his stores to keep them out of range of the Federal bombardment of the town. Bee relied on Confederate blockade runners to keep stocked his "Bee Block," also known as the "Bee Store."

properties.Name: Avery Research Center
properties.Description: 125 Bull St. Avery Research Center for African-American History and Culture. It was was established by the American Missionary Association and the Freedmen’s Bureau as the first free secondary school for Charleston's African-American population. Rev. F.L. Cardozo was able to secure a grant of $10,000 from Charles Avery's Avery Fund. Avery was a Methodist minister who lived in Pittsburgh. The institute became a public school in 1947. The public school merged with Burke High School in 1954.

properties.Name: Calhoun Street
properties.Description: Named after John C. Calhoun (1782-1850), the “Great Nullifier.” In 1824, John C. Calhoun was elected US vice-president under John Quincy Adams. He resigned in 1832 to lead the efforts to pass a law in South Carolina that would allow the state to nullify federal laws. For as long as there is racism, Calhoun will figure prominently. He called slavery a “positive good.” A statue of Calhoun was brought down in 2020 that towered over Marion Square for 124 years.

properties.Name: Gaillard Municipal Auditorium
properties.Description: 77 Calhoun St. Gaillard Municipal Auditorium. The City of Charleston built the auditorium and called it the Charleston Municipal Auditorium. The cost for the land and the buildings was $5,500,000. The complex covers 12 acres. The main auditorium sits 2,700. The Exhibition Hall is 14,000 sq. ft. and can be broken into sections to accommodate more than one event. It is currently named in honor of J. Palmer Gaillard (1920-2006). Gailliard was the mayor of Charleston from 1959-1975.

properties.Name: Arch Building
properties.Description: 85 Calhoun St. Arch Building. The building gets its name from the street-level arch in the center of the building. It is likely that through the arch wagons were able to access a yard for wagon trade in the back of the building. Charleston's Civic Design Center currently occupies the building.

properties.Name: John Fabre Jr. House
properties.Description: 6 Tradd. John Fabre Jr. House. The house was built on lot #7 of the "Grand Modell." John Fabre purchased the house after it was built. It had any number of other owners and uses until Susan Pringle Frost purchased the property along with others close by to prevent their demolition.

properties.Name: Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal (A.M.E.) Church
properties.Description: 110 Calhoun St. Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal (A.M.E.) Church. This is possibly the most persecuted church congregation in the United States. Free blacks and slaves formed the Free African Society in 1791. They built a church close to Hanover and Amherst in 1818. They then joined the African Methodist Episcopal Church and named their church Bethel Circuit. Among the founders of the Bethel Circuit was Morris Brown (1770-1849) and Denmark Vesey (c. 1767-1822). In 1822, slave owners were informed that Vesey was organizing a slave uprising. An investigation took place that resulted in Vesey being hanged along with 34 others. A mob soon thereafter burned Bethel Circuit. Morris Brown was not implicated but forced to leave the state. He and his family moved to Philadelphia where he became a bishop of A.M.E. Richard Cain (1825-1887) worked to reorganize the congregation after the Civil War. The congregation decided to change its name from Bethel Circuit to Emanuel A.M.E. Church. They completed a church building in 1872 at 110 Calhoun only to see it destroyed by the earthquake of 1886. The church was re-built in 1891. Dylann Roof opened fire in the church in 2015 and killed nine people.

properties.Name: Harleston-Boags Funeral Home
properties.Description: 121 Calhoun St. The (Edwin G.) Harleston-Boags Funeral Home. Harleston was a rice grower and sea captain. He used 121 Calhoun for a variety of purposes. The first floor was a funeral home for many years beginning in 1914. There was also a chapel that could seat 150 people. The second floor was a large hall for meetings, receptions, and entertainment. Harleston's son, Edwin A. Harleston, was a portrait artist and led efforts to establish the Charleston chapter of the NAACP in 1917.

properties.Name: 159 Calhoun St
properties.Description: The inconspicuous “DT” pattern in the concrete latticework leading into the College Lodge parking area is left over from the residence hall’s former identity as the The Charleston Downtowner Motor Inn.

properties.Name: Richard Holloway Tenement
properties.Description: 221 Calhoun St. Richard Holloway Tenement. Holloway was a carpenter and leader of Charleston's free black community. Holloway also built 96 Smith. Both houses have the piazzas under the main roof.

properties.Name: Saint Mark's Episcopal Church
properties.Description: 14 Thomas. St. Mark's Church. The congregation formed in 1865 and first gathered at the Orphan House Chapel on Vanderhorst Street. Rev. A. Toomer Porter severed as the church's rector for many years. Porter also founded the Porter Military Acadamy that was located at 167 Ashley Ave. and was the rector for the Church of the Holy Communion at 218 Ashley Ave.

properties.Name: Old Bethel Methodist Church
properties.Description: 222 Calhoun St. Old Bethel Methodist Church. This is the city’s 3rd oldest church. In 1880, it was moved from Pitt and Calhoun to make room for the Bethel Methodist Church. Francis Asbury (1745-1816) preached at Bethel in 1798. He is known as the "Father of American Methodism." The college named after him is in Wilmore, Kentucky.

properties.Name: Calhoun Securities Row Houses
properties.Description: 267-273 Calhoun St. Calhoun Securities Row Houses. Built on filled Bennett's Mill Pond. Although it was the Halsey Lumber Co. that operated on this portion of the pond, did the fill-in, and sold it off to the The Calhoun Securities Co. The company then re-sold 267 to Levi C. Boland. Boland was a travelling salesman. He built the house at 267 Calhoun. The Calhoun Securities Co. built 269-273. Boland built the curve in the piazza at 267 with no columnar support at the corner. And there is no columnar support for the two-story bays at 269, 271, and 273. The American Cancer Society combined all of the buildings from 2006-2007.

properties.Name: Sebring-Aimar House
properties.Description: 268 Calhoun St. (Edward) Sebring - (Charles Pons) Aimar House. Sebring worked for the State Bank of South Carolina. The bank constructed the buildings at 1 and 3 Broad. The house that Sebring built and lived in appears prominently in Henry Joseph Jackson's 1846 painting of the Mill Pond (View From the West). Sebring sold the house to Charles Pons Aimar in 1882. His family owned the house for another five generations. MUSC owns the house today.

properties.Name: Jonathan Lucas House
properties.Description: 286 Calhoun St. Jonathan Lucas House. Elaborate main entrance with elliptical fanlight. Lucas built the first water-powered and tide-powered rice mills. The house was made a part of The City Hospital when it was built at Calhoun and Lucas (now Barre) in 1887-88. It was called the Riverside Infirmary. The City Hospital became The Roper Hospital in 1904. After Roper built the Thompson Memorial Hospital in 1921, it changed the Riverside Infirmary to the R.A. Kinloch Home for Nurses. The Roper Hospital still owns the house.

properties.Name: Legare-Rhett House
properties.Description: 9 Thomas St. (James) Legare - (Robert Barnwell Sr.) Rhett House. Legare likely started building the house after buying the lot in 1832. Rhett bought the property in 1856. Rhett was a state legislator, attorney general, congressman, and U.S. Senator. He was known as the "Father of Secession" for his demands for states-rights and an independent southern Confederacy. Rhett's son, Robert Barnwell Rhett Jr., edited the Charleston Mercury as a secessionist newspaper until the Union Army started occupying Charleston in 1868. Tradition does not allow the gate on Vanderhorst to be opened. The fiancé of a soldier was told the gate would remain shut until he returned from the Civil War. He never returned.

properties.Name: Stolls Alley
properties.Description: Stolls Alley is named after blacksmith Justinus Stoll. Stoll's home was 7 Stoll's Alley. It was built around 1745. Prior to then, the street was known as Pilots Alley. Charleston's most famous blacksmith, Philip Simmons, forged a number of the alley's gates and other ironwork.

properties.Name: State Street
properties.Description: State street was first named Union Street in 1707 to commemorate the unification of England and Scotland. The name was changed to State in 1812.

properties.Name: Cannon Street
properties.Description: Like the neighborhood Cannonborough, the street is named after Daniel Cannon. He was a timberman. 135 Cannon Street was where the Hospital and Training School for Nurses was located.

properties.Name: Zion-Olivet United Presbyterian Church
properties.Description: 134 Cannon St. Zion-Olivet United Presbyterian Church. Zion Presbyterian began as a mission of 2nd Presbyterian in 1847. Olivet Presbyterian was a mission that met on George St.Zion and Olivet merged in 1959 and built the church at 134 Cannon.

properties.Name: Chalmers Street
properties.Description: Named after Dr. Lionel Chalmers (1715-1777). Chalmers purchased a lot on the street in 1757. He worked with Dr. John Lining (106 Broad) and Alexander Garden (96 Broad). The house Chalmers lived in was destroyed by a fire in 1778. Longest remaining cobblestone street in Charleston.

properties.Name: Old Slave Mart Museum
properties.Description: 6 Chalmers St. Old Slave Mart. In 1856, a city ordinance prohibited the public sale of slaves. This activity was occurring primarily at "the usual place" on the north side of the Custom House, or better known today as the Old Exchange Building. Among those who began conducting slave auctions on private property was Thomas Ryan. He later sold the business to Ziba Oakes. The location then became known as "the Mart." It remained in operation until Union bombardment during the Civil War forced "the Mart" to close down its business. The entrance to "the Mart" was actually on Queen Street. Inside "the Mart" there was a kitchen, an infirmary, and a 4-story jail or "barracoon" where the slaves lived prior to their sale. The only structure still left is the one facing Chalmers Street which is where the museum is today. The building was initially used for presenting the slaves and selling them. In the middle of "the Mart" was a corral or pen for holding the slaves. Miriam B. Wilson founded the Old Slave Mart Museum in 1938. The city now manages and operates the museum.

properties.Name: German Fire Steam Engine Company
properties.Description: 8 Chalmers St. German Fire Steam Engine Company. The building was constructed in response to the town's widespread fire of 1838. The building became a meeting hall after the fire company moved to 46 Wentworth (look for the Dalmatian lying in front of the building) in 1888. Today the building is office space.

properties.Name: The Pink House
properties.Description: 17 Chalmers St. The Pink House. Constructed partially out of Bermuda stone. Also has one of the last gambrel roofs in Charleston. The Pink House is one of the city’s oldest buildings. The house served as the studio for Alice Ravenel Huger Smith (1876-1958). A number of Smith's works are on view at the Gibbes Museum of Art. Smith traveled little. She preferred exploring the Lowcountry for subjects of her paintings. She was known to detest change and despised the automobile. All of her papers are contained at the South Carolina Historical Society. She is buried at Magnolia Cemetery.

properties.Name: Confederate Courtroom
properties.Description: 23-25 Chalmers St. Confederate Courtroom. The building sits on the back of the Confederate House. It was a US District Court from 1845-60. When Abraham Lincoln was elected President, Andrew G. Magrath (1813-1893) wrote, "For the last time I have, as a Judge, administered the laws of the United States... So far as I am concerned, the Temple of Justice, raised under the Constitution of the United States, is now closed. If it shall never again be opened, I thank god that its doors have been closed before its alter has been desecrated with sacrifices to tyranny." Magrath re-opened the "Temple of Justice" as the Confederate Courtroom.

properties.Name: German Friendly Society
properties.Description: 29 Chalmers St. German Friendly Society. Founded in 1766. The society formerly met on Archdale St. The society moved to 29 Chalmers in 1942. The Arion Society also meets at 29 Chalmers. The membership of the German Friendly Society is limited to 175. The society curates a museum in the building. Portraits of past officers hang on the walls. Some of the society's officers fought in the Revolutionary War.

properties.Name: Jane Wightman House
properties.Description: 36 Chalmers St. Jane Wightman House. Wightman was a free woman of African descent. Wightman also owned 38 Chalmers. Because of her properties on Chalmers, the street was sometimes referred to as "Mulatto Alley." Author Josephine Pinckney (1895-1957) bought and restored the house in the 1930s. She also added the piazza with the Federal Revival-style entrance. Pinckney is best known for Three O'clock Dinner which was published in 1945. She is buried at Magnolia Cemetery.

properties.Name: Chapel Street
