properties.Description: Chapel Street is a street without a chapel. It appears a chapel was supposed to be built at the corner of Chapel and Elizabeth. A chapel did once stand on the triangle that is now Fountain Park. The chapel was used by St. Luke's Episcopal until it moved to 22 Elizabeth St. The name of the street is not a reference to St. Luke's since the street was already named Chapel. St. Mark's Episcopal then used the chapel until its church was built on Thomas St. The chapel that was on Chapel was demolished in 1884. The Vanderhorst family once bought and owned much of the land along Chapel St.

properties.Name: Northeastern Rail Road Company Depot
properties.Description: 14 Chapel St. Northeastern Rail Road Company Depot. Restaurant ventures for many years have used the depot that replaced the first depot that was located at the site. The explosion that brought down the first depot happened on Feb. 18, 1865, three days after the evacuation of Confederate forces from Charleston. The explosion took some 150 lives and left that much more devastation in the town. Rather than continue his scorched earth policy in Charleston, General Sherman believed the town had suffered enough. "I doubt any city was ever more terribly punished than Charleston, but as her people had for years been agitating for war and discord, and had finally inaugurated the Civil War, the judgment of the world will be that Charleston deserved the fate that befell her."

properties.Name: Charlotte Street
properties.Description: Named after Charlotte Wragg, daughter of Joseph Wragg. The east end of the street is the location of the Carolina Gas Company. The plant was built in 1855. Three years later, the company merged with the Charleston Gas Light Company. During the Civil War, artillery struck the gas holder, but it miraculously did not explode. The gas holder was replaced in 1893. Workmen found in the bottom of the old gas holder an 8" artillery shell.

properties.Name: Robert Martin House
properties.Description: 16 Charlotte St. Robert Martin House. Martin was in the "wagon-yard" trade. The site was almost like a modern day truck stop, except the drivers would spend time trading the items they had on their wagons. The city’s first stationary bathtub is in the basement. It is 7’x 3’x 2’ and made out of granite from Winnsboro. Martin built the house next door (20 Charlotte) as a wedding gift for his daughter, Ellen.

properties.Name: Joseph Aiken House
properties.Description: 20 Charlotte St. Joseph Aiken House. Robert Martin lived at 16 Charlotte. He built the house at 20 Charlotte built as a wedding gift for his daughter. Martin's daughter, Ellen, married Joseph Aiken. Before the Civil War, Aiken was an attorney. During the war, he served with the Third South Carolina Cavalry. After the war, he worked as a shipping agent. Aiken was also a self-taught painter, sculptor, and architect. Records show Edward C. Jones was the architect. Aiken most likely designed the house with Jones' guidance.

properties.Name: J. Thomas Hamlin White House
properties.Description: 33 Charlotte St. J. Thomas Hamlin White House. White owned land and grew crops in the Christ Church Parish. After the Civil War, it was the headquarters of Maj. Gen. Daniel Edgar (Dan) Sickles (1819-1914). Sickles commanded the Dept. of the Carolinas during the Federal occupation of the South. His questionable character was not helped by his membership in New York City's Tammany Hall Gang and an affair with Spain's Queen Isabella II (1830-1904).

properties.Name: Chisolm House
properties.Description: Named after Chisolm's Mill that used to operate where the Coast Guard is located now. Alexander Hext Chisolm operated the mill. He was the son of George Chisolm (1772-1835) and Providence Hext Prioleau (1776 -1860). George Chisolm was an accountant and built the house at 39 East Bay in 1810. Alexander Hext Chisolm built the house at 172 Tradd St. Chisolm also built the superintendent's house for his mill at 190 Tradd. The mill that Chisolm built is at 200 Tradd.

properties.Name: Andrew B. Murray Vocational School
properties.Description: 3 Chisolm St. Andrew B. Murray Vocational School. The City of Charleston built the school and opened it in 1923. Andrew Buist Murray (1844-1928) grew up in an orphanage in Charleston and became a successful businessman and philanthropist. Murray helped pay for the construction of the school. The school was closed in 1970 and then became an office building for the Charleston County School District. The school district built a new office building at 75 Calhoun and abandoned the Murray school building. Developers purchased the building and converted it into condominiums.

properties.Name: 190 Chisolm St
properties.Description: Chisolm's Mill Superintendent's House.

properties.Name: Church Street
properties.Description: Church Street was one of the original streets of the 1672 Grand Modell. Even though the street is named for St. Philip's, it wasn't until 1738 that St. Philip's was located on Church St. The church was originally at Broad and Meeting.

properties.Name: Snowden House
properties.Description: 14 Church St. (Dr. William) Snowden House. Snowden's wife, Amarynthia, held meetings at the house to organize and found the Confederate Home and College. During the Civil War, Snowden turned the house into a hospital. He also buried silver in the backyard that was discovered in 1922.

properties.Name: George Williams Coach House
properties.Description: 19 Church St. George Williams Coach House. Williams built the coach house for his mansion at 16 Meeting. The house at 16 Meeting is now known as the "Calhoun Mansion." In 1940, the coach house was rehabilitated as a residence. Loutrel Briggs designed the garden. The brick wall that is attached to the south side of the house was the entrance for the horses and coaches.

properties.Name: 20-24 Church St
properties.Description: 20-24 Church St. The buildings from 20-24 Church were built from 1795-1809. James H. Ancrum, a descendant of William Rhett, was living at 20 Church by 1809 after selling the William Rhett House (54 Hasell).

properties.Name: 35 Church St
properties.Description: 35 Church St. Thomas (Young) - (Joseph Johnson). Thomas Young built the house in 1770. Joseph Johnson (1776-1862) later lived in the house. Johnson was the author of Traditions and Reminiscences of the American Revolution. Johnson was also a physician, an intendant (the present-day title is mayor) of Charleston, and president of the Second Bank of the United States. In 1941, the house became the home of sculptor Wilmer Hoffman (1889-1954).

properties.Name: George Eveleigh House
properties.Description: 39 Church St. George Eveleigh House. Eveleigh's fortune was made on Indian trade. The exterior walls are made out of small yellowish red bricks that were likely imported from New England. Eveleigh put the house up for sale in 1753. For an idea of where the sea reached into the town at that time, Eveleigh gave "on White Point" as the location for the house.

properties.Name: James Veree House
properties.Description: 58 Church St. James Veree House. Veree also built 56 and 60. Emily Whaley (1911-1998) lived in 58 Church. She and Loutrel Briggs designed the garden which became the subject of Mrs. Whaley and Her Charleston Garden. The book was published in 1997. The garden is open to the public. Donations are welcome.

properties.Name: Thomas Rose House
properties.Description: 59 Church St. Thomas Rose House. Rose owned land and grew crops on the Ashley River. The ghost of Dr. Joseph Brown Ladd also lurks in the house. Ladd's body was carried into the house after he fought and lost a duel defending the honor of an actress who went by the name of Perdita.

properties.Name: Capers-Motte House
properties.Description: 69 Church St. (Richard) Capers- (Jacob) Motte House. Capers was a land owner in the Christ Church Parish. Motte served as the city's public treasurer for 27 years. The treasurer, who was appointed and regulated by the Assembly, kept the provincial government's funds in his personal possession, subject to a costly bond. Like banks do today, Motte was able to charge commissions for acting as the city's bank. The deeper the lot, the more utilitarian. At the far back of the property is an orangery. The Adamesque main house contrasts with the Gothic kitchen and slave quarters. One of the privies is now a garden shed. Also once the home of artist Alice Ravenel Huger Smith.

properties.Name: Robert Brewton House
properties.Description: 71 Church St. Robert Brewton House. One of the earliest surviving examples of the Charleston single house. (The earliest single houses did not have a piazza.) The house was built from 1721-1740. The designer of the garden is Loutrell Briggs.

properties.Name: Home of Edwin DuBose Heyward
properties.Description: 76 Church St. Home of Edwin DuBose Heyward. 76 & 78 have been combined into one house. If President George Washington spoke from the house's balcony during his visit in 1791, it was a different balcony. The current balcony was installed around 1820. The house was also the home of Edwin DuBose Heyward (1885-1940), author of Porgy (published in 1925).

properties.Name: Louis Danjou House
properties.Description: 77 Church St. Louis Danjou House. Danjou was a grocer. He operated his business on the ground floor and lived in the upper two floors. 75 Church was his warehouse and stable. Before moving to Charleston, Loutrel Briggs had an office at 77 Church.

properties.Name: Heyward-Washington House
properties.Description: 87 Church St. (Daniel) Heyward- (George) Washington House. Daniel Heyward (1720 - 1777) was a large land owner and crop grower. The Heyward family was among the original settlers of Charles Towne. They accumulated enormous wealth through the slave trade and cultivating plants such as rice. The house Daniel Heyward built at 87 Church was passed down to his son, Thomas. In 1791, President George Washington was the guest of Thomas Heyward (1749 - 1809) at 87 Church. Heyward along with Arthur Middleton, Edward Rutledge, and Thomas Lynch were the four representatives from South Carolina who signed the Declaration of Independence. The drawing room mantel at 87 Church was designed by Thomas Elfe. He also designed the drawing room mantel for 15 Legare. Elfe built and lived in the house at 16 Clifford. In 1929, The Charleston Museum and the Preservation of Old Dwellings (present-day Preservation Society of Charleston) spared the house at 87 Church from demolition. The house was restored and re-opened as Charleston's first house museum. The garden is maintained by the Garden Club of Charleston.

properties.Name: Catfish Row
properties.Description: 89-91 Church St. Catfish Row. The buildings were constructed for tenement housing and business. They are among Charleston's earliest mixed-use developments. From the street-level windows vendors sold mainly cabbage which gave the buildings the name Cabbage Row. Dubose Heyward changed the name to Catfish Row for his book, Porgy, that was published in 1929. The actual Catfish Row was on Bay (present-day East Bay) Street.

properties.Name: Cooper-Bee House
properties.Description: 94 Church St. The (John) Cooper- (Thomas) Bee House. Construction was completed in 1765. The drawing room ostensibly is where Robert Y. Hayne, John C. Calhoun, et al, wrote out the draft for the Ordinance of Nullification in 1830.

properties.Name: The (1st) Bank of the United States Building
properties.Description: 100 Church St. The (1st) Bank of the United States Building. Construction of the bank's Charleston branch began in 1785. The bank was chartered once the building was completed in 1790. The bank moved to 80 Broad upon its completion in 1804.

properties.Name: 121-123 Church St
properties.Description: The addition is one of the few examples of modern architecture in downtown Charleston.

properties.Name: The Dock Street Theater
properties.Description: 135 Church St. The Dock Street Theater. The original Dock Street Theater was built in 1735 and was called the New World Theatre. The front of the theatre faced what was known then as Dock Street. It was the first building on the continent built specifically for theatre. The first performance was the The Recruiting Officer in 1736. The first opera on the continent was also performed at the Dock Street Theatre. The title was Flora, or Hob in the Well. The name of the street was changed to Queen Street in 1738. Fire destroyed the New World Theatre in 1740. In 1809, Alexander Calder and his wife bought the buildings that replaced the New World Theatre to establish The Planter's Hotel. It is at the Planter's Hotel that is supposedly where the first Planter's Punch was mixed and served. By 1885 the hotel had fallen into disrepair. The City of Charleston saved the building in 1935 as a Works Progress Administration Project (WPA). The work was finished in 1937 to become the the Dock Street Theatre. The first performance was appropriately The Recruiting Officer. Another renovation was completed in 2010.

properties.Name: The “Jolly Corner"
properties.Description: 137 Church St. The “Jolly Corner." The building was originally a smith shop. A cannonball from the Civil War went through the roof and was found under the ground floor.

properties.Name: French Huguenot (Protestant)
properties.Description: 140 Church St. French Huguenot (Protestant). The first French Huguenots arrived in Charles Towne in 1680. They organized their first congregation in 1687. The church remains the only French Calvinist-Protestant congregation in the United States.

properties.Name: Alexander Perronneau Tenements
properties.Description: 141-145 Church St. Alexander Perronneau Tenements. Perronneau was a merchant and a French Huguenot. The tenements might have also been "Pirate Houses." If so, pirates would have constructed tunnels connecting the tenements to the Cooper River to conduct their illicit trade. The base of 141 Church is made out of Bermuda stone.

properties.Name: St. Phillip's
properties.Description: 146 Church St. St. Philip’s. Organized in 1680. Oldest Episcopalian congregation in Charleston and first Anglican congregation south of Virginia. The first church was located at Broad and Meeting. It was built in 1681. A grander second St. Philip's was built at 146 Church from 1710-38. Significant funding came from duties on "rum, brandy, and slaves." The church caught fire in 1796 but was saved by a slave who tore off the burning shingles from the building. He was then given his freedom. Another fire in 1835 brought down the whole church. The replacement was built from 1835-1838. The steeple was designed by Edward Brickell White. Some referred to the church as the "lighthouse church" because a light placed in its steeple helped guide ships to port. Native Charlestonians ("Bin Yere") are buried in the graveyard next to the church. Non-native ("Cum Yere"), including John C. Calhoun, are buried across the street. "The Footpad's Memorial" is also in the western cemetery. Footpads were those who were known to rob and kill Nicholas John Wightman and tragic others.

properties.Name: Mary Molony House
properties.Description: 158 Church St. Mary Molony House. John and Mary Molony were from Ireland. After immigrating from Ireland to Charleston in 1840, they constructed a building to live in and operate a store. The building burned down in 1861. After the Civil War, they constructed a new building out of red brick that is the one standing today.

properties.Name: Wilson-Sottile House
properties.Description: 11 College Way. (Samuel) Wilson-Sottile House. Among his many business interests, Wilson owned and operated a successful retail, grocery, and tea business on King Street called the Charleston Tea Pot. The Sottile family purchased the house after Wilson's death in 1909. The College of Charleston acquired the house from the Sottile family in 1964.

properties.Name: Coming Street
properties.Description: Affra Harleston Coming was the wife of John Coming. The Comings met aboard the Carolina. John Coming died in 1698 and left his estate to Affra (ca. 1625-1699) even though the law was such at the time that Affra was not entitled to her husband's full estate. She appealed to the colony's General Assembly for the full estate. The General Assembly agreed to let Affra receive the full estate with the stipulation that she grant a portion of her husband's estate to the Church of England. This amounted to 17 acres of glebe lands for St. Philip’s. Upon Affra's death, the land that is today known as Harleston Village was left to her nephews, Elias Ball and John Harleston. Evidence of Affra's gift can be found on a memorial stone on Glebe Street on the east side of Grace Episcopal Church.

properties.Name: William James Rivers House
properties.Description: 40 Coming St. William James Rivers House. William James Rivers (1822-1909) was a writer and teacher. He used part of his house for a boys academy. Among those who attended the academy was poet Henry Timrod (1828-1867). Working as a professor by the time the Civil War broke out, Rivers was exempt from fighting. Rivers was teaching in Columbia near the end of the Civil War and witnessed General Sherman and his Union army burn the city. The devastation inspired Rivers to write his novel Eunice: A Tale of Reconstruction Times in South Carolina.

properties.Name: Cathedral of St. Luke and St. Paul
properties.Description: 126 Coming St. Cathedral of St. Luke and St. Paul. Completed in 1816. The steeple that was once on top of the building was too heavy and started splitting the church's walls. The steeple was removed and replaced with a Gothic Revival parapet. With numerous land owners from around the neck of the peninsula in attendance, the church became known as the "planter's church." The church had to replace its pastor, W.B.W. Howe, after the Civil War because he refused to pray for the President of the United States. The church was designated the Cathedral Church of the Episcopal Diocese of South Carolina in 1963.

properties.Name: Kahal Kadosh Beth Elohim Cemetery
properties.Description: 189 Coming St. Kahal Kadosh Beth Elohim Cemetery. The cemetery was originally Isaac DaCosta's private burial ground. The property was transferred to Beth Elohim in 1764. More than 600 graves can be identified within the cemetery's 3/4 acres.Kahal Kadosh Beth Elohim Cemetery. The cemetery was originally Isaac DaCosta's private burial ground. The property was transferred to Beth Elohim in 1764. More than 600 graves can be identified within the cemetery's 3/4 acres.

properties.Name: Blake's Tenements at Court House Square
properties.Description: 4 Court House Square. Blake's Tenements at Court House Square. During the time the South Carolina State House was standing, the square was known as State House Alley. In 1787, Columbia became the state capital. Then in 1788 the old State House burned. A new building was constructed that resembled the State House and was designated the Charleston District Court House. Along with the new building came the new name of Court House Square for the alley. Charleston County purchased Blake's Tenements in 1967 for office space. The brickwork is laid in Flemish bond on the facade and with English bond on the sides.

properties.Name: Cumberland Street
properties.Description: The Duke of Cumberland was the title George II gave his son Prince William Augustus (1721-1765). The aftermath of the Duke of Cumberland fighting Tories led to him being called "Butcher" Cumberland. Horse racing was most important to Cumberland second to defending the English crown. The Duke of Cumberland was crowned King George III of England in 1760. It was under the reign of George III that England lost the American Revolutionary War that began on July 4, 1776.

properties.Name: Old Powder Magazine
properties.Description: 21 Cumberland St. Old Powder Magazine. The Old Powder Building is the oldest public building in South Carolina. It is situated within the city's walls that stood between 1703-1719. Governor Nathaniel Johnson and William Rhett directed the construction of the building. The brick walls are 36" thick. And the attic still contains several tons of sand that are supposed to fall in case of an explosion. Historic Charleston Foundation currently owns the building that The Colonial Dames of America in The State of South Carolina operate as a museum.

properties.Name: Martschink Building
properties.Description: 26 Cumberland St. Martschink Building.

properties.Name: Judge Nicholas Trott House
properties.Description: 83 Cumberland St. Judge Nicholas Trott House. Name the judge who issued Stede Bonnet’s death sentence in 1718? Nicholas Trott. Trott issued the death sentence for Stede "The Gentleman Pirate" Bonnet and his crew. They were hanged over the course of five weeks near White Point Garden/Oyster Point beginning on Dec. 10, 1718. All of them were buried below the high water mark.

properties.Name: East Battery
properties.Description: East Battery is more work-in-progress than a street. It started where the marsh and sand met 40 East Bay. This originally was the site of Granville Bastion. At low tides, sand can still be seen on the southern side of 40 East Bay. High Battery was constructed first. The first version was completed in 1755. It stretched from Granville Bastion to White Point Garden at a spot called Broughton Battery. Weather and the ocean quickly took its toll on the battery made of mud, sand, and fascines (large bundles of sticks). The weather and ocean continue to require modifications and reconstruction to East Battery, South Battery, and Murray Boulevard. An additional seawall is now even being proposed to protect the southern end of Charleston from severe weather and rising sea levels. Most of the mansions on East Battery were built between 1820 and 1850.

properties.Name: John Ravenel House
properties.Description: 5 East Battery. John Ravenel House. Ravenel had many business interests, including serving as president of the South Carolina Rail Road. Upon his death, Ravenel's son, Dr. St. Julien Ravenel, inherited the house. Ravenel designed and built "Little David," a semi-submersible torpedo boat that the Confederates used in the Civil War. After the Civil War, Ravenel worked to develop the mining of phosphate. Ravenel's wife, Harriott Horry Rutledge, was the author of such books as Charleston: The Place and the People. Ravenel's brother, William, lived at 13 East Battery. The house became a bed and breakfast in 1977. Its nickname is the "Pink Palace."

properties.Name: Robert William Roper House
properties.Description: 9 East Battery. Robert William Roper House. Roper was the son of Thomas Roper (1760-1829).Thomas Roper requested that his son leave his estate the Medical Society if he were to die without an heir. The Medical Society used the proceeds from sale of 9 East Battery and other properties to build a hospital that was named The Roper Hospital. Richard Hampton Jenrette (1929-2018) bought the house in 1968. Jenrette was an investment banker and one of the founders of Donaldson, Lufkin, and Jenrette. Nine East Battery was the first of a number of historical properties Jenrette owned and restored. The Prince of Wales was Jenrette's guest when the prince visited Charleston not long after Hurricane Hugo. The hurricane lifted the Atlantic Ocean five feet into the first floor of the house.

properties.Name: William Ravenel House
properties.Description: 13 East Battery. William Ravenel House. The house's porte-cochere runs below the drawing room. The drawing room extends the width of the house and is perhaps the largest in the city. William's brother, John, lived at 5 East Battery.

properties.Name: Julius M. Visanka House
properties.Description: 19 East Battery. Julius M. Visanka House. Visanka was a haberdasher. Albert Simons mixed different architectural styles including corner brick quoining, a Renaissane loggia entry, and Greek Revival tripartite windows. Once completed, it was one of the most expensive houses in Charleston.

properties.Name: Edmondston-Alston House
properties.Description: 21 East Battery. (Charles) Edmondston- (Charles) Alston. General P.G.T. Beauregard watched the bombardment of Ft. Sumter on April 12, 1861, from the house's piazzas. On December 11, 1861, General Robert E. Lee stayed at 21 East Battery after a fire destroyed much of the town. Part of the house is a museum that the Middleton Place Foundation operates. Members of the Alston family reside on the 3rd floor. The carriage house operates as a bed and breakfast.

properties.Name: Charles H. Drayton House
properties.Description: 25 East Battery. Charles H. Drayton (1847-1915) House. Drayton was the grandson of Dr. Charles Drayton (1743-1820). Drayton mined phosphate at Drayton Hall, his family's plantation.

properties.Name: Porcher-Simonds House
properties.Description: 29 East Battery. (Francis J.) Porcher - (John C) Simonds House. Francis James Porcher (1821-1872) was a cotton broker and was in attendance at the South Carolina Secession Convention. After the Civil War, he was the president of the Atlantic Phosphate Company. Porcher constructed the house in the Italianate style. The changes that Simonds made in the 1890s are Italian Renaissance Revival.

properties.Name: Henry Porter Williams House
properties.Description: 31 East Battery. Henry Porter Williams House. Williams' father, George W. Williams, built and owned the house at 16 Meeting that is known as the Calhoun Mansion. Henry Porter Williams had the chance to live at 16 Meeting but chose to live at 31 East Battery instead.

properties.Name: East Bay Street
properties.Description: East Bay Street was originally Bay Street. It was also the only street between the town and the marshes and tidal creeks of the Cooper River. Charles Towne became a walled city beginning in 1703. The wall ran between Granville Bastion (40 East Bay) and Craven's Bastion (200 East Bay). The wall was further connected to Carteret Bastion (155 Meeting) and Colleton Bastion (51 Meeting). When it was complete, Charles Towne was one of only three walled town's in North America. The walls started coming down in 1719 to allow the town to expand.

properties.Name: George Chisholm House
properties.Description: 39 E Bay St. George Chisholm House. The drawing room once contained Tiffany gold leaf ornamentation. It was removed in the early 1970’s. The garden was designed by Loutrel Briggs.

properties.Name: Capt. James Missroon House
properties.Description: 40 East Bay St. Capt. James Missroon House. It was from Missroon’s Southern Wharf that Robert Smalls commandeered Planter from the Confederacy on May 13, 1862. The house is now the main office for the Historic Charleston Foundation. 40 East Bay was also the southeast corner of the city's walls when they were built beginning in 1703. The bastion was named after George Carteret (1610-1680), the 2nd Earl of Granville. Carteret was one of the eight Lord Proprietors. Remains of the Granville Bastion were found in the basement during the house's renovation in 1925.

properties.Name: George Sommers House
properties.Description: 43 East Bay St. George Sommers House. The house was built during the 1740s on part a of Lot Number 1 of the Grand Modell. George Sommers purchased the property in 1755. Some years later, John Teasdale purchased the property from the Sommers family. Teasdale was the first to ship cotton from South Carolina to Europe. The Hanahan family has owned the house since the 1930s. The property includes a part of the south end of what was once a wall around Charleston. Brick is in place in the driveway that marks where the wall stood.

properties.Name: Carolina Yacht Club
properties.Description: 50 East Bay St. Carolina Yacht Club. Founded in 1883 for “yachting, bathing, social, literary, and aquatic purposes.” The older portions of the club were built in the 1850s and were used as office space for commodity brokers and accountants.

properties.Name: Caspar Christian Shutt House
properties.Description: 51 East Bay St. Caspar Christian Shutt House. Shutt was a German merchant. One of the largest Charleston single houses ever built. The piazzas are in the "proper" progression: Doric (1st), Ionic (2nd), and Corinthian (3rd). The piazzas were completed in 1836.

properties.Name: The Charleston Club
properties.Description: 53 East Bay St. The Charleston Club. The club was chartered by the South Carolina General Assembly in 1852 and has been located at 53 East Bay since 1958. The lack of a sign might give a hint of the club's exclusive membership.

properties.Name: Vanderhorst Row
properties.Description: 76-80 East Bay St. Vanderhorst Row. Construction completed in 1800. Named after Arnoldus Vanderhorst (1748-1852). He served as mayor of Charleston (1790-1792) and governor of South Carolina (1794-1976). The land he owned for growing crops was most of Kiawah Island.

properties.Name: Rainbow Row
properties.Description: 79-107 East Bay St. Rainbow Row. The original use of the houses was for commerce below and living space above. Reconstruction after the Civil War applied little to the old part of Charleston. Beginning in the 1920s, Susan Pringle Frost and others formed the Society for the Preservation of Old Dwellings to save historical buildings from demolition. Among them were six properties that Frost purchased that today comprise a large part of Rainbow Row. Frost then worked to re-sell the properties to preservation minded buyers.

properties.Name: William Stone House
properties.Description: 83 East Bay St. William Stone House. Stone was an English merchant and a Tory. The building passed through a succession of merchants until Susan Pringle Frost bought the house in 1941. She rehabilitated the house and gutted the brick warehouse in the back. Loutrel Briggs designed the courtyard garden in the back that incorporates the walls of the warehouse.

properties.Name: Deas-Tunno House
properties.Description: 89 East Bay St. Deas-Tunno House. The Blue House of Rainbow Row. The house is especially rare for having a full basement. The basement is constructed out of stones that sailing ships used or ballast.

properties.Name: Ancrum's Wharf Building
properties.Description: 90 East Bay St. Ancrum's Wharf Building. Parker Quince and John Ancrum received the grant for the site in 1793 and completed the existing building sometime during the 1790's. It is one of Charleston's few surviving 18th century wharf buildings.

properties.Name: Inglis Arch
properties.Description: 91 East Bay St. Inglis Arch. After the Revolution, the mercantile firm of Leger and Greenwood rebuilt on the site. The firm imported tea prior to the war. It was their tea that was seized by demonstrators for the Charlestowne Tea Party on Dec. 16, 1773.

properties.Name: 99-101 East Bay St.
properties.Description: 99-101 East Bay St. Dorothy Porcher Legge purchased 99-101 East Bay from Susan Pringle Frost. Legge then used the color of pink to paint the exterior. The color inspired her neighbors to paint their exteriors with a pastel color. All of the buildings that were painted with a pastel color are now a part of the section of Charleston that is known as Rainbow Row. A city ordinance is in place that requires the owners of buildings along Rainbow Row maintain their exteriors with a pastel color.

properties.Name: Joseph Dulles House
properties.Description: 103 East Bay St. Joseph Dulles House. Descendants of Joseph Dulles are Former Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and the founder of the CIA, Allen Dulles. Joseph Dulles used the building for his residence and accounting practice. Anna Wells Rutledge installed the off-center gable roof when she owned the house in the 1930's. The street-level arched openings probably once served as openings for carriages.

properties.Name: Coates's Row
properties.Description: 114-120 East Bay St. Coates's Row. The houses were completed in 1806. Harris' Tavern was located at 120 East Bay. It then became the French Coffee House. Supporters of the French Revolution were called Jacobins. The Jacobins in Charleston held their meetings at the French Coffee House. The rouged brick at 118 East Bay was designed to make the Carolina “grey” brick look like Philadelphia red brick.

properties.Name: Walker, Evans, & Cogswell Building
properties.Description: 117 East Bay St. Walker, Evans, & Cogswell Building. Walker, Evans, & Cogswell was established in 1821. A part of the company's printing business was the minutes of the Secession Convention, the documents that were produced by the convention, currency for the Confederacy, government bonds, stamps, and a prayer book for soldiers. During the time the Union was bombarding Charleston, the company moved its operations to Columbia. The company returned to Charleston after the Civil War and remained in business until 1982.

properties.Name: Old Exchange Building and (English) Provost Dungeon
properties.Description: 122 East Bay St. Old Exchange Building and (English) Provost Dungeon. Construction was completed in 1771. Elevated basement, Palladian windows. Situated where the Half-Moon Battery was. The town's merchants and land owners convinced the S.C. Assembly to pass an act in 1767 to pay for a building to accommodate the growing import/export business. It was also used to store the tea that was taken during the Charlestowne Tea Party in 1773 and re-sold to help finance the Revolutionary War. When the British re-occupied the town from 1780-1782, the building was used as a dungeon. Among the Patriot prisoners was Isaac Hayne. He was found guilty of treason and hanged on Aug 4, 1781. Many others suffered and died in the prison. In 1787, South Carolina congressmen ratified the U.S. Constitution at the Exchange Building after the capitol in Columbia suspiciously went up in flames. In 1791, the Exchange Building was the site for many of the social events surrounding George Washington's visit to the town. For many years the building served as a U.S. post office. Today the building is a museum owned and operated by the Old Exchange Commission.

properties.Name: Farmers' and Exchange Bank
properties.Description: 141 East Bay St. Farmers' and Exchange Bank. The buiilding was almost turned into a parking lot. Senator Fritz Hollings restored the building in 1970 and used it for office space for his staff. In 1973, the building was listed as a National Historic Landmark.

properties.Name: The (first) McCrady Tavern
properties.Description: 153 E Bay St. The (first) McCrady Tavern. Edward McCrady operated a tavern at 153 East Bay until he was imprisoned in St. Augustine during the Revolutionary War. When he returned, he opened a restaurant at 2 Unity Alley that was attached to the tavern at 153 East Bay St. In 1791, the Society of the Cincinnati held a dinner for President George Washington in the tavern's "long room." Since the President's visit, the building has served many purposes but is now back to being a tavern and restaurant. Edward McCrady lived at 44 St. Philip Street.

properties.Name: Wagener - Ohlandt Building
properties.Description: 161 East Bay St. (Frederick W.) Wagener - Ohlandt Building. Wagener ran a commodity business and was the chairman of the board of the S.C. Interstate and West Indian Exposition that took place in Charleston from 1901-1902

properties.Name: The U.S. Custom House
properties.Description: 200 East Bay St. The U.S. Custom House. Initially Edward C. Jones was going to be the architect. Then Federal authorities chose Ammi B. Young since he had designed a similar building in Boston. Due to the Civil War, it took 30 years to build. 200 East Bay was also the northeast corner of the city's walls when they were built beginning in 1703. A bastion was built on the corner and named after William Craven (1608-1697). Craven was one of the eight Lord Proprietors.

properties.Name: 235 East Bay St.
properties.Description: The site where a bridge connected Charlestown to Colleton Square. The mansion was located in an area of town known as Colleton Square. Sir Peter Colleton was the original owner of the land. The borders of Colleton Square were from 225 East Bay, north to Pinckney Street, west close to Meeting Street, the south close to North Market St. The land remained in Colleton's family until John Colleton sold the land to George Hunter, Thomas Ellery, and Charles Pinckney (1699 - 1758) in 1736. In 1745, Pinckney began the construction of "The Governor's Mansion" at the corner of Guignard and East Bay. Pinckney and his wife, Eliza, spent minimal time in the mansion. Most of their time was spent living, working, and raising their children, among whom was Charles Cotesworth Pinckney, on a plantation they owned along the Wappoo Creek. Charles and Eliza Pinckney also lived in London while representing the colony's trade interests from 1753-1758. Meanwhile, Pinckney rented his mansion to royal governors, namely James Glen, William Henry Lyttelton, Thomas Boone, and Charles Greville Montagu. In 1788, the Pinckney family and all those owning an interest in Colleton Square gave Charlestown the land with the condition that it be used for market purposes. Otherwise, the land would revert back to the families.

properties.Name: Bennett's Rice Mill
properties.Description: 290 East Bay St. Bennett's Rice Mill. Governor Thomas Bennett Jr. (1781-1865) built the mill. The Bennett family sold the mill in 1911. Various businesses used the building until 1960 when Hurricane Donna leveled all of the building except for the western façade. The structure now finds itself in the center of the S.C. State Ports Authority's Union Pier Terminal.

properties.Name: Blake-Grimké House
properties.Description: 321 East Bay St. (William) Blake- (John Faucheraud) Grimké House. William Blake was the son of Joseph Blake. Joseph Blake built his wealth on the slave trade. John Faucheraud Grimké later owned the house. His wife, Mary Smith, went by "Polly." Polly was a daughter of Thomas Smith. The Smith family maintained, among other land holdings, the plantation they called Belmont. Mary Grimké managed her family's slaves in such a manner that two of her daughters, Sarah (1792-1873) and Angelina (1805-1879), became outspoken abolitionists.

properties.Name: Gadsden-Morris House
properties.Description: 329 East Bay St. (Philip) Gadsden-Morris House. Philip Simmon’s fabricated the "Snake Gates." They were designed by Samuel Gaillard Stoney. The design is a reference to the flag designed by Christopher Gadsden (Philip’s father) for the US Navy in 1775. The flag has a coiled rattlesnake and the words “Don’t Tread on Me." For Native Americans, slaves, and wildlife, the question must be who is treading on whom?

properties.Name: Faber House
properties.Description: 635 East Bay St. Faber House. Faber owned farmland on the Edisto River. The house was finished in 1839. The Historic Charleston Foundation saved the house from demolition in 1965. Arther Ravenel became the owner in 1971 and converted the house into offices and apartments.

properties.Name: The Cigar Factory
properties.Description: 701 East Bay St. The Cigar Factory. The Charleston Manufacturing Co. was chartered in 1880. The company built its mill in 1882. The mill was constructed to process cotton and was designed with the latest advances in electricity, steam heat, and fire safety. The mill operated successfully until the earthquake of 1886. The Charleston Manufacturing Co. shut down the cotton mill and started leasing the building. In 1903, the American Cigar Company started occupying the building. At its peak, the company employed 1,400 workers at the site and produced 1.5 million cigars a day. When the U.S. Federal government began requiring warning labels on tobacco products in the late 1960s, the American Cigar Company ended its operations in Charleston. The building was occupied by various tenants until it was converted into residential and commercial space.

properties.Name: Elizabeth Street
properties.Description: Named after Elizabeth Wragg (1736-1773). She was the wife of Peter Manigault (1731-1773). Slave trade combined with Elizabeth's estate enabled Manigault to become the wealthiest man in England's North American colonies.

properties.Name: New Tabernacle Fourth Baptist Church
properties.Description: 22 Elizabeth St. New Tabernacle Fourth Baptist Church. There is supposed to be a steeple in the northwest corner. And the brick is supposed to be stuccoed. Patrick O'Donnell was the contractor. Another O'Donnell's folly is at 21 King St. New Tabernacle Fourth Baptist Church purchased the building in 1950 from the St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

properties.Name: Aiken-Rhett House
properties.Description: 48 Elizabeth St. (William Sr. and Jr.) Aiken- (I'On) Rhett House. The slave quarters are Gothic Revival (1830s). William Aiken Sr. gained ownership of the house in 1827. Between Aiken and his wife, Harriet Lowndes, they owned enormous areas of land, as in all of Jehossee Island. Jefferson Davis was a guest of William Aiken Jr. when he visited Charleston in Nov. 1863. Harriet Lowndes was known for boundless extravagance, thus making her house a prime target for looting after the Civil War. Today, the ghost of Harriet Lowndes laments lost riches and power. The Charleston Museum acquired the house in 1975 then sold it to the Historic Charleston Foundation in 1995.

properties.Name: David Saylor House
properties.Description: 4 Elliott St. David Saylor House. Saylor was a cooper. All of the house is made of brick that is laid in Flemish bond. Also unique are the segmental arched openings and the corbelled cornice of exposed brick.The roof is made of wood shingles that have since been covered with a roof of pantiles.

properties.Name: George Washington Cooper House
properties.Description: 13 Franklin St. George Washington Cooper House. Cooper was an attorney. The clapboard house is notable for its open work columns on the portico and piazza. As a child, DuBose Heyward (1885-1940) lived next door at 15 Franklin.

properties.Name: Marine Hospital
properties.Description: 20 Franklin St. Marine Hospital. The hospital was completed in 1834. From 1891-1939, the hospital served as an orphanage for black children. The orphanage was founded by Rev. Daniel J. Jenkins. Children in the orphanage made up the famous Jenkins Orphanage Band. The building today is administrative offices for the Housing Authority of Charleston.

properties.Name: Fulton Street
properties.Description: It is not known for whom the street is named. Prior to World War II, the street was the heart of Charleston's "Red Light" district.

properties.Name: Grace Peixotto House
properties.Description: 11 Fulton St. Grace Peixotto (1817-1880) House. Peixotto was a brothel madam. She called 11 Fulton the "Big Brick." Peixotto also built 9 Fulton. She denied that her business was "disorderly" by stating, "I know that you policemen have to make your money on the side and that we have to pay you for protection, and that's all right. I know that you have to have a raid every once in a while and fine us, and that's all right. But there's one thing I object to. I object to you writing the charge against me for maintaining a disorderly house. I want to have you know that I have the most quiet, respectable, ladylike whores south of the Mason-Dixon Line." The "Big Brick" was able to continue operating as a part of Piexotto's estate upon her death in 1880. The U.S. Navy pressured the brothel to close in 1942. It is believed that Peixotto inspired the character Belle in Margaret Mitchell's Gone With the Wind.

properties.Name: George Street
properties.Description: The street is named for George Anson (1697 - 1762). George St. and Anson St. were a part of the section of town that was named Ansonborough. There is speculation that George Anson won Ansonborough in a card game.

properties.Name: Middleton-Pinckney House
properties.Description: 14 George St. (Francis Motte) Middleton- (Thomas) Pinckney House. In 1826, the Mrs. Barnard (Juliet Gibbes) Elliott bought the house. The house remained in the Elliott family for about another 50 years. During that time, Boundary Street (present-day Calhoun) was created by filling in the marsh to the east and the creek to the north. Since 1985, the house has served as the main office for the Spoleto Festival. The festival for the arts takes place in the spring and lasts for two weeks. In 2001, an endowment of $5.3 million was funded for maintaining the house.

properties.Name: Harrison Randolph Hall
properties.Description: 66 George St. Harrison Randolph Hall. In 1770, Benjamin Smith left £1,000 to establish a local college. It took another 20 years before the College of Charleston was founded. Harrison Randolph Hall's portico and wings were added in 1850. They were designed by Edward Brickell White. He also designed the college's Porter's Lodge. To walk from George Street to Randolph Hall one must walk under the famed Cistern. To the left (on the west side of the courtyard) is the Italianate-style Towell Library. It was completed in 1856.

properties.Name: Gibbes Street
properties.Description: Named after William Gibbes. Gibbes was a merchant and owned ships. His home was 64 South Battery.

properties.Name: Parker-Drayton House
properties.Description: 6 Gibbes St. (Issac) Parker - (Col. William) Drayton House. William Drayton (1776 - 1846) attained the rank of colonel during the War of 1812. He was also a U.S. Congressman for South Carolina from 1825 -1833. He left South Carolina during the nullification crisis and moved to Philadelphia. Drayton sold 6 Gibbes St. to Nathaniel Heyward in 1837. Heyward then gave the house to his daughter, Elizabeth. and her husband, Charles Manigault.

properties.Name: Gillon Street
properties.Description: Alexander Gillon commanded the South Carolina Navy during the American Revolution. John Champneys (1743-1820) was a merchant and a large land owner along the Wando River near present-day Ravenel. He also owned a wharf at the end of Broad Street behind the Custom House. A plat in 1784 shows that it was all of the area between present-day Exchange Street and Gillon Street. Champneys grew rice and many other plants. Dr. David Ramsay (who lived at 92 Broad) described Champneys’ plantation containing one of the Lowcountry’s “most elaborate early gardens.” The garden covered 26 acres, and in his vast garden Champneys crossed  Rosa chinensis (‘Old Blush’) and Rosa moschata to produce "Champney's Pink Cluster." Champneys shared cuttings of his Pink Cluster with French-born botanist Philippe Noisette. Noisette's garden was located close to the present-day campus of The Citadel. Noisette sent cuttings from his garden to Paris where his brother, Louis Noisette, worked as a nurseryman. Noisette used the cuttings to cultivate another variety of rose that he sent back to his brother. The rose is today known all over the world as the Blush Noisette.

properties.Name: St. Philip's Parsonage House
properties.Description: 6 Glebe St. St. Philip's Parsonage House. The house was first known as the St. Philip's Glebe House. The College of Charleston used the building for its first classes in 1790. The College of Charleston purchased the house from St. Philip's in 1957. Today, the house serves as the residence for the president of the College of Charleston.

properties.Name: Hasell Street
properties.Description: Pronounced "Hazel." Named after James Hasell Jr. Hasell was the husband of William Rhett's granddaughter, Sarah Wright. Most of the buildings on Hasell were constructed shortly after the fire of 1838.

properties.Name: St. Johannes Lutheran
properties.Description: 48 Hasell St. St. Johannes Lutheran. Those who left St. John's Lutheran when the church stopped conducting its services in German built St. Johannes Church. Services were held in German at St. Johannes until 1924.

properties.Name: Col. William Rhett House
properties.Description: 54 Hasell St. Col. William Rhett House. The house was built from 1711-1728 thus making it one of the oldest in the city. In 1706, Col. Rhett commanded a small local fleet that drove off a combined French and Spanish invasion. In 1718, Rhett captured pirate Stede Bonnet at Cape Fear. After Rhett's death, Judge Nicholas Trott married Rhett's widow. It was Trott who issued Stede Bonnet his death sentence. In 1809, James H. Ancrum sold the house. Ancrum inherited the house from his mother who was a great-grand-daughter of Col. Rhett. Ancrum and his wife then leased 20 Church. Ancrum's wife was a daughter of Col. William Washington. Col. Washington lived a few doors down at 8 South Battery.

properties.Name: Synagogue of Kahal Kadosh Beth Elohim
properties.Description: 90 Hasell St. Synagogue of Kahal Kadosh Beth Elohim. Beth Elohim organized the Reformed Society of Israelites in 1824. The building is the second oldest synagogue in the US and the oldest in continuous use. And It was the first Jewish congregation in the U.S. to use an organ in its services.

properties.Name: St. Mary’s Roman Catholic Church
properties.Description: 95 Hasell St. St. Mary’s Roman Catholic Church. The mother church of Catholicism in the Carolinas and Georgia. John S. Gogdell painted the crucifixion inside the church.Admiral François Joseph de Grasse’s daughters and many other French Catholics are buried in the cemetery. A Jewish synagogue is across the street from St. Mary's, and the French Hugenot Protestant Church is just a few blocks to the south of St. Mary's on Church St. Jews, Protestants, and Catholics fought bitterly across Europe but managed to get along in the small settlement of Charlestowne.

properties.Name: Camden and Tower Depots
properties.Description: 36-37 John St. Camden and Tower Depots. Built for the South Carolina Railroad. The Camden Depot was possibly in reference to the Camden Branch of the South Carolina Railroad. The depots run the width of the block which the Charleston Area Regional Transit Authority (CARTA) uses as a bus terminal. CARTA's offices are at 36 John St. At 25 Ann St. is the Children's Museum of the Lowcountry. The Charleston Visitors Center is on the Ann Street end of the depots and uses the address 375 Meeting. "The Best Friend of Charleston," the first locomotive to pull a South Carolina Railroad train, is on display within the visitors center.

properties.Name: John Robinson House
properties.Description: 10 Judith St. John Robinson House. Robinson worked as a merchant in Charleston for 53 years. 6, 8, 15, & 17 Judith were all tenement houses that Robinson owned. He lived in 10 Judith. Peter Fayssoux Stevens lived in the house from 1902-1910. Stevens was an Episcopal minister. He also commanded the The Citadel's Battalion of State Cadets. In January of 1861, the battalion fired from a battery on Morris Island its first shots at the Federal supply ship, Star of the West, to prevent it from reaching Union soldiers at Ft. Sumter. Some consider these shots the first ones of the Civil War.

properties.Name: King Street
properties.Description: During the time that the Lord Proprietors owned the colony of Carolina and for as long as Charles Towne was a walled city, Queen Street was known as Dock Street. There was no King Street. What is now King St. was no more than a very large trail or path on the peninsula's highest ground for driving cattle to the town’s first beef market at the corner of Broad and Meeting. The street was referred to as "The Broad Path," the "High Way," or the "Broad Road." It was in 1734 that Dock Street was officially named Queen St. in honor of Caroline of Ansbach, the wife of King George II. There is no record of when King Street was named or for which king it honored. In 1911, Murray Boulevard was completed. King Street was then extended from South Battery to Murray Boulevard. Charleston was no exception to urban blight as people gradually abandoned city centers to live in suburbs. Former director of the Historic Charleston Foundation, Frances R. Edmunds, called King Street, "the weak, sick spine of the city." Today the city's spine is stronger. Millions of dollars have been spent on such projects as the South Carolina Railroad Complex and parking facilities to attract retail establishments, restaurants, hotels, and other businesses to King Street.

properties.Name: Fort Sumter House
properties.Description: 1 King St. Fort Sumter House. As might be expected, there was considerable controversy surrounding the construction of the Fort Sumter House. Except for the Murray Building on Chisolm, no building south of Broad comes close to the Fort Sumter's House scale and height. The Fort Sumter House was orginally called the Fort Sumter Hotel. John F. Kennedy (1917-1963) was a guest at the hotel. It so happened that JFK's mistress, Inga Arvad, was also a guest. When not romancing in the hotel, they would roam around town in JFK's 1940 Buick convertible and window shop on King Street. The hotel was converted into condominiums in 1974.

properties.Name: Thomas Lamboll House
properties.Description: 19 King St. Thomas Lamboll House. Completed in 1739. The piazza is Greek Revival. Thomas Lamboll (1694-1744) owned a wharf at the end of King St. where South Battery. He and his wife, Elizabeth Pitts Lamboll (1725-1770 also tended a large garden that started at the house and reached all the way to the Ashley River. They also maintained an orange grove on their plantation on James Island. John Bartram (1699-1777) visited Charleston for the first time in 1760 and was likely a guest of the Lambolls. Elizabeth Lamboll consulted regularly with Bartram about plants and caring for plants.

properties.Name: Patrick O' Donnell House
properties.Description: 21 King St. Patrick O' Donnell House. Also known as “O’Donnell’s Folly." O'Donnell spent 18 years (1852-1870) building the house for his fiancé. It took so long she married someone else. O'Donnell then lived in the house alone. Also the childhood home of author Josephine Pinckney. In 2007, a fund raiser was held at the house for Barak Obama's presidential campaign.

properties.Name: Miles Brewton House
properties.Description: 27 King St. Miles Brewton House. Colonel Brewton's main business was the slave trade, thus the question whether the chevaux-de-frise (curly hair) at the top of the fence was to deter escape or entry. He also was responsible for managing the gun powder for the Carolina province and was the foreman of the grand jury that indicted Stede "The Gentleman Pirate" Bonnet. Brewton and his family were lost at sea in 1775. Descendants of Miles Brewton still own the house.

properties.Name: John Prue House
properties.Description: 41 King St. John Prue House. Prue was a carpenter. In his will that he wrote in 1772, he bequeathed his "house and lot" to the "proposed college" that eventually became the College of Charleston.

properties.Name: Grimké-Fraser House
properties.Description: 55 King St. (Frederick) Grimké - (Alexander) Fraser House. Frederick Grimké (1705-1778) built the house that his descendant Charles Fraser (1782-1860) eventually owned. Fraser studied studied art under Bishop Robert Smith. Fraser specialized in miniature portraits. Fraser's most famous portrait is the one he did of Marquise de Lafayette during his visit to Charleston in 1825. In 1854, Fraser published My Reminiscences of Charleston. Fraser is buried in St. Michael's graveyard.

properties.Name: Lewis Timothy House
properties.Description: 97 King St. Lewis Timothy House. Lewis Timothy (1699-1738) arrived in Philadelphia in 1731. His parents were French Huguenots. They moved to The Netherlands to escape religious persecution. In addition to French and Dutch, Timothy learned to speak fluently German and English. Timothy also learned to be a printer and was hired by Benjamin Franklin (1706-1790). On November 26, 1733, Franklin and Lewis entered into an agreement for Lewis to publish the South Carolina Gazette. After Lewis died in 1738, his wife Elizabeth continued to publish the newspaper under the name of her 13-year-old son, Peter Timothy. The newspaper gained considerable value when it became the official printer for the Assembly, the colony’s governing body. Elizabeth Lewis was also named the postmaster for Charlestowne. In 1745, Elizabeth turned over the newspaper business to her son and opened a bookstore. During the American Revolution, Peter Timothy promoted the Patriot cause in the South Carolina Gazette. As soon as the British were able to occupy Charlestowne, they banished Peter from the city and ended the publication of the South Carolina Gazette. Wherever Peter Lewis decided to go, he died at sea trying to get there. Like Elizabeth Timothy, Peter Timothy's widow, Ann, carried on with Timothy's work by publishing the South Carolina Gazette once the British evacuated Charleston in 1783. From 1786-1802 the newspaper was published in Dr. John Lining’s house at 98 Broad. In 1800, the newspaper was re-named the Charleston Courier. Ann Lewis sold the newspaper in 1802. In 1866, The News began to be published. The two newspaper were merged in 1872 and named the The News and Courier. After another merger with The Evening Post in 1992, the paper was re-named the The Post and Courier.

properties.Name: Hesse Grocery
properties.Description: 147-149 King St. Hesse Grocery. Ernst J. Hesse was born in Germany and immigrated to Walhalla, SC, in 1860. During the Civil War he served in the German Hussars of Charleston. He then became successful in the grocery business. Since 1978, the building has been the main office for the Preservation Society of Charleston.

properties.Name: The Carolina Rifles Armory
properties.Description: 160 King St. The Carolina Rifles Armory. The Carolina Rifle Club was organized in 1869 after the Federal government banned the formation of military units after the Civil War. When Federal occupation of Charleston ended in 1878, the Carolina Rifle Club reverted back to a military unit. The military unit bought 160 King Street in 1888. The 76 men who were members of the military unit stored their Springfield rifles on the second floor. The military unit eventually became a part of the National Guard. The armory is today filled mostly with books and is called Buxton's Bookstore.

properties.Name: Charleston Library Society
properties.Description: 164 King St Charleston Library Society. The society was organized in 1748. Of the original 16 persons who founded the Charleston Library Society, nine were merchants. The others were land owners (2), lawyers (2), a schoolmaster, a wig maker, and a physician. In 1773, a committee was formed "for collecting materials for promoting a Natural History of this province." These materials and the efforts of this committee are recognized as being responsible for the development of the Charleston Museum. Early members of the Library Society also left substantial bequeaths for the founding of the College of Charleston. Members have access to a collection of books, historic manuscripts, and archival material that dates back to the 15th century and to the library's highly qualified and knowledgeable staff. The library also serves as a venue for music performances and lectures.

properties.Name: Riviera Theatre
properties.Description: 227 King St. Riviera Theatre. Albert Sottile constructed the theatre. He was the President of Pastime Amusement Company. The Art Deco is in the Egyptian style. On the same site was the Academy of Music which opened in 1869. Its acoustics attracted such performers as Theodore Thomas's Orchestra, Maurice Barrymore, The Grau Opera Company, John Drew, The Booths, Joseph Jefferson, Mrs. Fiske,Lillian Russell, Otis Skinner, Irving & Terry, Weber & Fields, Bernhardt, Schumann-Hinck, Maude Adams, Paderweski, and many others. The Riviera stayed in operation until 1978. It is now used as meeting and conference space for Charleston Place.

properties.Name: Kress Building
properties.Description: 281 King St. Kress Building. The building was a part of a chain of Kress department stores. Samuel Kress was the owner. He had an architecture division at his main office in New York City. Charleston's Kress store was at the corner of King and Beaufain before moving to 281 King. The Kress department stores closed in the 1990's.

properties.Name: Croghan's Jewel Box
properties.Description: Christian Henry Faber built 306 and 308 King St. Croghan's Jewel Box has been in business at 308 King St. for over 100 years. William Joseph Croghan founded the business. His granddaughter, Mariana Ramsey Hay, now manages the business.

properties.Name: Gloria Theater Building
properties.Description: 327-329 King St. Gloria Theater Building. 327 and 329 King were originally tenement housing. From 1923-1927, the Gloria Theatre was constructed in the back of 327 and 329 King. Its entrance was at 329 King. The theatre premiered Gone With the Wind in 1939. In the audience was Alicia Rhett (1915-2014) who played the role of India Wilkes in the movie. The Gloria Theatre closed in 1975. The College of Charleston purchased and remodeled the building and named it the Sottile. The entrance of the Sottile is at 44 George St.

properties.Name: Garden Theater
properties.Description: 371 King St. Garden Theater. The theater had its opening on January 14, 1918. Silent movies were shown at first. A piano-organ was played to accompany the movies. American Fotoplayer made the piano-organ. Margaret Dengate was one of the players of the theater's American Fotoplayer. "I could make the sounds of shooting pistols, slamming doors, creeks and others." The building has had extensive renovations and represents mostly a shell of its original design.

properties.Name: Francis Marion Hotel
properties.Description: 387 King St. Francis Marion Hotel. The hotel is one of the tallest buildings in Charleston. It replaced the Zion Presbyterian Church (123 Calhoun). The church was the largest brick church in Charleston. It sat 2,500 people. Francis Marion (1732 - 1795) was known as the "Swamp Fox." Instead of facing the British head on in the Revolutionary War, he adopted a more guerrilla style of warfare that the Native Americans practiced. Marion Square Realty Co. built the hotel at a cost of $1.5 million. A partner in the company was former mayor of Charleston, T.T. Hyde. In 1952, the hotel became the first fully air-conditioned hotel in Charleston.

properties.Name: St. Matthew's German Lutheran Church
properties.Description: 405 King St. St. Matthew's German Lutheran Church. The church was built from 1967-1872. The church was re-built exactly the way it was after a fire destroyed it in 1965. The steeple is 265 feet high and is the tallest steeple in South Carolina.

properties.Name: American Theater
properties.Description: 446 King St. American Theater. The theater was named "in honor of service men, war warkers and Americans all over the nation whose efforts are being bent toward victory over the axis powers." The theater seated 900 people. War restrictions prevented the installation of air conditioning. Fans were put in place on either side of the stage, in the roof, and in the rear of the building. The theater was remodeled in 1947 and then closed in 1977. Patrick Properties has owned the building since 1996 and is currently available for special events, music performances, and lectures.

properties.Name: William Aiken House
properties.Description: 456 King St. William Aiken House. Aiken was president of the S.C. Canal and Rail Road Co. The railroad began operation on Christmas Day, 1830. The property is a National Historic Landmark as the birthplace of America's first railroad to use a steam locomotive to pull a train of cars on a track in regular service.

properties.Name: 3 Ladson St
properties.Description: 3 and 3 1/2 Ladson St. The residence of Loutrel Briggs (1893-1977) during the 1930’s & 40’s. Note his initials inscribed in the exterior wall above the windows on the left side of the house.

properties.Name: Ladson Street
properties.Description: Named after James Ladson (1753 -1812). Ladson served as the lieutenant governor and was a land owner and crop grower. Ladson Street cuts through land William Bull once owned. Bull lived at 35 Meeting. His son-in-law, John Drayton Sr., lived at 2 Ladson. The street is now what likely connected the two houses.

properties.Name: John Drayton House
properties.Description: 2 Ladson St. John Drayton House. William Bull (1683-1755) owned the lot and then gave it to his son-in-law, John Drayton (1714-1779) in 1742. Drayton likely built the house. William Bull lived at 35 Meeting.

properties.Name: Lamboll Street
properties.Description: Named after property owner Thomas Lamboll. He lived at 19 King. The street has also gone by Dedcott's Alley, Rivers Street, and Kincaid Street.

properties.Name: Augustus Taft House
properties.Description: 57 Laurens St. Augustus Taft House. An easement is in place on the house that restricts the owners to be full-time residents. Houses in downtown Charleston that have been purchased as second and third homes have displaced people trying to live and work downtown.

properties.Name: Legare Street
properties.Description: The name is pronounced "Luh-GREE." The street is named after Solomon Legaré (1703-1774). Legaré was a French Huguenot and worked as a silversmith. He also bought and sold real estate.

properties.Name: Kinloch-Huger House
properties.Description: 8 Legare St. Kinloch-Huger House. Patrick O'Donnell was the contractor. O'Donnell also built 10 Legare. O'Donnell lived at 21 King which became known as "O'Donnell's Folly." A bust of the house's current owner is above the front door.

properties.Name: Simmons-Edwards House
properties.Description: 14 Legare St. (Francis) Simmons - (George) Edwards House. Simmons owned land and grew crops on Johns Island. He lived at 14 Legare while his wife, Ruth Lowndes, resided at 131 Tradd. By living in such an arrangement, Simmons became known as "the celibate bridegroom." George Edwards added the Pineapple Gates after he purchased the property in 1816. The pineapples are supposed to resemble Italian pine cones.The garden was planted in 1950.

properties.Name: John Fullerton House
properties.Description: 15 Legare St. John Fullerton House. Fullerton was a carpenter and a member of Christopher Gasdens's "Sons of Liberty." Fullerton died on the eve of the Declaration of Independence. British staff officers added insult to injury by occupying his house from 1780-1782. It is also storied that a duel was fought with one shooter firing from the upper porch of 14 Legare and the other from a third-story window in 15 Legare. Fullerton constructed the house at 15 Legare out of cypress trees. Thomas Elfe built the drawing room mantel.

properties.Name: Dr. Robert Trail Chisholm House
properties.Description: 23 Legare St. Dr. Robert Trail Chisholm House. Also home of Herbert Ravenel Sass (1862-1960). Sass was a prolific writer about the history and natural history of South Carolina. A private driveway connects the lot to the street. The driveway gates were made in 1817.

properties.Name: Trapier Gervais House
properties.Description: 29 Legare St. Trapier Gervais House. Gervais was the rector for many years of St. John's Episcopal Church on Johns Island. The house was also the birthplace of author Josephine Pinckney (1895-1957). Pinckney is best known for Three O'clock Dinner which was published in 1945. She is buried at Magnolia Cemetery. The lot was number 233 on the Grand Modell and remains one of the largest residential lots in the city.

properties.Name: Hannah Heyward House
properties.Description: 31 Legare St. Hannah Heyward House. Hannah Shubrick Heyward (1759-1829) was the wife of William Heyward (1753 - 1786). William was the brother of Thomas Heyward, a signer of the Declaration of Independence. The Heywards' son James died in a hunting accident in 1805. He still appears at the house as a ghost! Augustine Thomas Smythe (1842 - 1914) bought the house in 1868. During the Civil War, he used a gas-filled balloon to fly up and spy on Federal gunboats. His letters and correspondence were used for the writing of a book titled Days of Destruction: Augustine Thomas Smythe and the Civil War Siege of Charleston. The Smythe family still owns the house.

properties.Name: Sword Gate House
properties.Description: 32 Legare St. Sword Gate House. Solomon "the Huguenot" Legare built the first house on the street sometime before 1740. From 1819 through 1848, Anne Talvande managed a "select academy for young ladies" in the house. Mary Boykin Chesnut (1823-1886) was a student of the academy. Chesnut published her diary that she titled Mary Chesnot's Civil War. Historian C. Vann Woodward won a Pulitzer Prize in History in 1982 for his annotated edition of the diary. The gates came from the guardhouse that once stood at 83 Broad. Christopher Werner made the gates in 1838. The crossed swords are symbols of authority. The house is 17,000 sq. ft.

properties.Name: James Streater Glenn House
properties.Description: 37 Legare St. James Streater Glenn House. Glenn was a land owner and crop grower. Augustine Smythe bought the property in 1903 for his daughter, Susan Bennett. Susan Bennett was the wife of John Bennett (1865-1956). Even though John Bennett was from Ohio, he wrote widely about Charleston in his novels Madam Margot, Doctor to the Dead, and The Treasure of Peyre Gaillard. Bennett's other works were children's books and a treatise on the Gullah language. Bennett, Hervey Allen (1889-1949), and Dubose Heyward (1885-1940) founded the Poetry Society of South Carolina in 1921.

properties.Name: Charles Elliott House
properties.Description: 43 Legare St. Charles Elliott House. Elliott owned land and grew crops near Rantowles. Elliott's daughter, Jane, was the wife of Col. William Washington (1752-1810). When Washington met Elliott's daughter, Jane, she made for him a flag from a damask curtain that Washington and his regiment carried into all the battles they contested in 1781. A similar scene was depicted in Margaret Mitchell's Gone With the Wind. William married Jane on April 21, 1782. They lived on Jane's father's plantation near Rantowles and owned the house at 8 South Battery. Among the crops that grew on the plantation was Washington's thoroughbred breeding operation.

properties.Name: 93-95 Lenwood Blvd
properties.Description: 93 and 95 Lenwood used to be one building that stood on the intersection of Lenwood and Tradd. The U.S. government used the building as a hospital. The building was divided and moved to their current locations in 1874.

properties.Name: Line Street
properties.Description: Named for the line of fortifications to protect the city during the War of 1812.

properties.Name: 44 Line St.
properties.Description: 44 Line St. The former engine repair shop for the South Carolina Rail Road. The South Carolina Canal and Railroad Company (SCCRR) was chartered in 1827 to connect Charleston with Hamburg. The distance was 136 miles. The railroad was needed for transporting cotton to Charleston's port. A short six-mile stretch west from Charleston was completed in 1830 on which operated the country's first regularly scheduled passenger train. The train was pulled by the locomotive called Best Friend of Charleston. The locomotive can be seen at the visitors center at 375 Meeting.

properties.Name: Calvary Episcopal Church
properties.Description: 106 Line St. Calvary Episcopal Church. The congregation was organized in 1847.

properties.Name: Logan Street
properties.Description: Named for William Logan. The cemetery behind and to the south of building was  the graveyard for St. Peter's Episcopal Church. The church was constructed from 1834-1836. It burned down in the fire of 1861 and was not re-built.

properties.Name: Frost House
properties.Description: 4 Logan St. Frost House. Dr. Edward Frost built the house for his son. Susan Pringle Frost (1873-1960) lived in the house in the early 1900’s. Frost organized and served as the first president of the Preservation Society of Charleston. She was also a leader in the suffrage movement in Charleston.

properties.Name: St. Peter's Church
properties.Description: 10 Logan St. St. Peter's Church. At the beginning of the War Between the States, there were 10 Episcopal churches in downtown Charleston, but only St. Michael's and St. Peter's were located south of Broad. St. Peter’s burned in 1861. There are no photographs or historic descriptions of the church. The congregation was organized in the summer of 1834, and the church was consecrated on December 30th, 1835. The original congregation included both black and white parishioners. They worshiped according to the Oxford Theology, which is often referred to as “high-church.” It parallels in many ways a Catholic order of worship Among those who attended the church were the Barnwells and deSaussures. A "rather unattractive" condominium building stands on the site today. The church's cemetery wraps around the south and west side of the lot.

properties.Name: Magazine Street
properties.Description: The street is named for a series of powder magazines that were built at the western end. The first, built about 1737, was called the New Magazine to distinguish it from the old one on Cumberland St. A second and larger one was built in 1748 and stood until after the Revolution. The adjoining area of four acres had been set aside in 1680 as public land and was used as a cemetery. Later, the magazines, the Poor House, hospitals, the Work House for runaway slaves, and the City Jail were built on the square bounded by Magazine, Mazyck (now Logan), Queen, and Back (now Franklin) streets.

properties.Name: Old Jail
properties.Description: 21 Magazine St. Old Jail. On the "Ichongraphy" of 1739, there appears a "Work House" in the vicinity of 15 Magazine St. It was built primarily for runaway slaves. Their "work" entailed walking on a treadmill to power a corn mill. Slaves were flogged if they refused to walk on the treadmill. The Work House was also the site for executions. After Denmark Vesey was hanged in 1822, free Black sailors had to stay in the jail according to the Negro Seaman Acts while their ships were in the Charleston Harbor. A new Work House was built in 1850. All that was left standing after the earthquake of 1886 was demolished. The jail at 21 Magazine was built beginning in 1802. It was turned over to the Charleston Housing Authority in 1939. It stayed vacant for 60 years until it was conveyed to the American College of Building Arts. A developer purchased the property for $2 million in 2016. Across the street (north of Magazine) is the Robert Mills Manor. Construction of the apartment buildings began in 1939. Under the apartment buildings is the "paupers cemetery." It is also the final resting place for however many died or were killed in the Work House and jail and British soldiers that fought in the Revolutionary War. If any remains were discovered during the construction of the Robert Mill Manor, they were not documented.

properties.Name: Carrington-Carr House
properties.Description: 2 Meeting St. (Waring P.) Carrington- (Minnie Spell) Carr House. The house was completed in 1892. Waring P. Carrington married Martha Williams, a daughter of George W. Williams. Martha Williams built the house at 2 Meeting with the $75,000 she found on a satin pillow that her father gave to her as a wedding gift.

properties.Name: John Edwards House
properties.Description: 15 Meeting St. John Edwards House. Edwards was a member of John Rutledge's Privy Council in 1779. Auguste de Grasse, (1765-1845), his family, and four sisters stayed at the house after fleeing Sainte-Domingue in 1793. De Grasse held the title of Comte de Grasse-Tilly. De Grasse's father, François Joseph Paul de Grasse (1722-1788), held the title of Comte de Grasse. François Joseph Paul de Grasse led the French navy's blockade of the Chesapeake Bay before England's Gen. Cornwallis surrendered to the Continental Army in 1783. Two of de Grasse's sisters died in Charleston in 1799 from yellow fever. They are buried at St. Mary's.

properties.Name: Calhoun Mansion
properties.Description: 16 Meeting St. Calhoun Mansion. The house was built by George W. Williams. Part of Williams' wealth came from being a blockade runner during the Civil War. Patrick Calhoun bought the house after Williams' death. Calhoun was the grandson of John C. Calhoun. The stock market crash of 1929 wiped out Calhoun's fortune forcing him to sell the mansion at public auction to settle his debts. The house is 24,000 sq. ft. and has 35 rooms.

properties.Name: Thomas Heyward House
properties.Description: 18 Meeting St. Thomas Heyward House. Thomas' brother, Nathaniel might have built the house before 1803. Otherwise, it was built by Thomas Heyward Jr. (1746-1809) after 1803. Heyward was a lawyer and a large land owner. He was one of four representatives from the colony of South Carolina to sign the Declaration of Independence. James Adger (1777 - 1858) also lived in the house. Shipping, banking, and many other business interests possibly might have made Adger at one point the richest man in South Carolina.

properties.Name: Young-Motte House
properties.Description: 30 Meeting St. (Thomas) Young- (Col. Isaac) Motte House. It is believed that Young began the construction of the house and sold it to Motte before it was completed. Isaac Motte (1738-1795) rose to be colonel under General William Moultrie (1730-1805). During the British occupation of Charleston, Motte's house was the headquarters for British commanders. It said that while the British were evacuating on December 14, 1882, their Hessian mercenaries were not with them. They were supposedly hiding in the chimneys of Motte's house.

properties.Name: Daniel Elliot Huger House
properties.Description: 34 Meeting St. Daniel Elliot Huger House. Capt. John Bull (d. 1768) bought this lot in 1759. At the time it extended from Church to Meeting. Someone in the Bull family built the house, either John himself, or his widow Mary (d. 1771), or the Bull's granddaughter, Elizabeth Blake. In 1775, England's Royal Governor William Campbell and his wife Sarah Izard moved into the house. Sarah was Elizabeth's cousin. Campbell's stay was short. He avoided potential harm on Sept. 15, 1775, by slipping out of the back of the house, rowing down Vanderhorst Creek, which is present-day Water Street, and boarding His Majesty's Tamar. He remained on the Tamar until Henry Clinton arrived to organize England's attack on Charleston. Campbell was put in command of the gun-deck on the Bristol. He died not long after the Battle of Sullivan's Island from the wounds he incurred. The woodwork inside the Huger House resembles that of the Miles Brewton House, thus likely the work of James Brown. William Elliott Huger bought the house in 1818. The property continues to be owned by the Huger family.

properties.Name: William Bull House
properties.Description: 35 Meeting St. William Bull House. William Bull (1683-1755) was the first royal lieutenant governor. William Bull’s son, William Bull II (1710-1791), also served as a lieutenant governor. In 1761, William Bull II negotiated peace with Native Americans to help end The French and Indian War. Bull remained a Loyalist. He left Charleston along with the British troops who evacuated Charleston in 1782. He pursued his studies in The Netherlands to be a doctor. He died in London, England, on July 4, 1791.

properties.Name: James Mitchell House
