properties.Description: 43 Meeting St. James Mitchell House. Mitchell was a cooper. Elizabeth E. Jenkins (1919-2012) lived for many years in the house. Jenkins served as president of Charleston's Junior League, the Preservation Society of Charleston, and the College of Charleston Alumni Association. She was also a life trustee of the Historic Charleston Foundation and director emeritus of the Preservation Society of Charleston.

properties.Name: The Robert M. Allan House
properties.Description: 47 Meeting St. The Robert M. Allan House. The white Lady Banks rose that is still growing in the garden was probably planted by Edward Barnwell (1813-1885). Barnwell also did most of the house's additions to accommodate his 17 children.

properties.Name: Nathanial Russell House
properties.Description: 51 Meeting St. Nathanial Russell House. The house was built from 1808-1811. It is famous for its Federal townhouse architecture, a free-flying staircase that rises three floors without visible support, oval rooms, and Adamesque decoration.The Charleston Preservation Society bought the house in 1955 and converted it into a museum. The house was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1974. 51 Meeting was also the southwest corner of the city's walls when they were built beginning in 1703. A bronze plaque hangs on a brick pier between the Nathaniel Russell House and First Scot's Presbyterian Church that marks the location of Colleton Bastion. The bastion was named after John Colleton (1608-1666). Colleton was one of the eight Lord Proprietors.

properties.Name: Timothy Ford House
properties.Description: 54 Meeting St. Timothy Ford House. Timothy Ford (1762-1830) built the house with Adamesque interiors from 1800-06. Ford was Born in Morristown, N.J., Ford served in the Continental Army in his youth and later studied law in New York. In 1785 he moved to Charleston, S.C. and established a law practice with his brother-in-law Henry W. DeSaussure. Their law firm trained many South Carolinians for law careers, including John C. Calhoun. Ford also owned plantations and served in the S.C. legislature. The Marquis de Lafayette stayed with Ford when he visited Charleston in 1825. The house is also where Louis Agassiz often stayed during his visits to Charleston to attend and participate in science lectures. Agassiz would have been the guest of Dr. Edmund Ravenel (1797-1871) when he owned the house with his wife and Ford's daughter, Charlotte Matilda. Ravenel practiced medicine but is better known for his contributions to conchology and natural history.

properties.Name: First Presbyterian Church
properties.Description: 57 Meeting St. First Presbyterian Church. Also known as the First Scots Presbyterian. 12 Scottish families founded the church after splitting off from Independent (Congregational) Church in 1731. They called the church "Scots Kirk." The first church building was replaced in 1814 by the one standing today. Thus, the church building is the fifth oldest in Charleston. The seal of the Church of Scotland is in the window over the main entrance. More than 50 headstones in the graveyard date back to before 1800.

properties.Name: Branford-Horry House
properties.Description: 59 Meeting St. The (William) Branford - (Elias) Horry House. Horry was Branford's grandson. He was also the president of the South Carolina Canal and Railroad Co. from 1831-1834. The Dependency (61 Meeting) was the stable for the Brandford-Horry House.

properties.Name: Dependency of the Brandford-Horry House
properties.Description: 61 Meeting St. Dependency of the Brandford-Horry House. The dependency served as the stable. Of those who have lived in the house is Judge Julius Waites Waring (1880-1968). His first wife was Annie Gammell. Waring divorced Gammell after meeting Elizabeth Hoffman. Hoffman divorced her husband, Henry Hoffman, to marry Waring. Charleston society frowned severely upon such marital rearrangement. The social standing of Elizabeth and Julius Waring deteriorated further when Elizabeth Waring labeled white Southerners "degenerates" in a speech to the Charleston YMCA. In 1945, Judge Waring threw down the gauntlet by ruling in favor of the NAACP and Septima Clark (1898-1987) demanding equal pay for white and black teachers. And in 1947, Judge Waring ruled in 1947 that people of African descent must be allowed to vote in the SC primary elections.

properties.Name: Philip Moore House
properties.Description: 65 Meeting St. Philip Moore House. In 1914, the house became the home of Julius Herman Rast. He was a mechanic who moved to Charleston from New York City. While in New York, he worked as the superintendent of the Knickerbocker Cycle Co. and the Stanley Cycle Co. One of his achievements was inventing a clamp for the bicycle's seat post. After moving to Charleston, he come up with the "Rast Incline Attachment." The device allowed the front seats of a car to slide and recline, the likes of which are still used today. The device also made possible the recliner chair. He likely developed the device on the gasolne-powered car he had parked close to his house. Rast was the first to drive an automobile on the streets of Charleston.

properties.Name: John Cordes Prioleau House
properties.Description: 68 Meeting St. John Cordes Prioleau House. John Cordes Prioleau was the brother of Catherine Cordes Ravenel (1745 - 1832). Catherine was the mother of Edmund Ravenel (1797 - 1871). Also the home of Dr. Charles U. Shepherd (1804-1886). While attending Amherst, Shepherd studied with naturalist Thomas Nuttall (1786-1859). Shepherd served as the chair of chemistry at MUSC from 1834-1861. He returned to MUSC for a few years after the end of the Civil War. In addition to his work at MUSC, Shepherd worked to develop industry in Charleston. He was among the first to promote the local potential for mining phosphate and grew and sold tea. His tea farm was in Summerville. In 1963, Shepard's tea plants were transplanted to a 127-acre potato farm located on Wadmalaw Island. William Barclay Hall purchased the farm in 1987. Hall is a third-generation tea taster who received his formal training during a four-year tea apprenticeship in London, England. Hall developed his farm into a commercial operation that is today called the Charleston Tea Garden. Shepherd's farm is now a part of a subdivision called Newington Plantation Estates, and his lab is now the residence at 8 Ropemaker's Lane.

properties.Name: South Carolina Society Hall
properties.Description: 72 Meeting St. South Carolina Society Hall. The "Two-Bit Club" founded the society in 1737. Members of the club were primarily French Huguenots. When they met, they would all contribute 15 pence or "two bits" to help needy Huguenot families. They also supported orphanages and schools. Frederick Wesner designed the portico with the Doric and Ionic orders. In the pediment is the society's seal and the motto, "Posteritati."

properties.Name: St. Michael’s Church
properties.Description: 80 Meeting St. St. Michael’s Church. St. Michael's represents the law according to God in Charleston's Four Corners of Law. The St. Philip's congregation built the first church on the site. The St. Philip's congregation re-located to their new church on Church Street in 1738. The St. Michael's congregation completed its brick and stucco church in 1761. St. Philip's burned down in 1835, therefore St. Michael's is the oldest church building in Charleston. The height of the steeple is 186'. The eight bells that ring from the steeple were imported from England in 1764. They have crossed the Atlantic six more times. The British hauled them off when they evacuated Charleston in 1782. A London merchant bought the bells and sent them back to St. Michael's. They were put in safe storage in Columbia during the Civil War only to be burned along with the rest of Columbia in 1865. The metal was salvaged and sent to England to be re-cast. In 1993, the bells were shipped to and from London for repairs. Time in Charleston used to go according to timekeepers ringing the bells of St. Michael's. They chimed the bells every quarter hour. In 1946, an electric clock was installed to ring the bells. The eight bells ring in a pattern called "changes." Changes ring out also at St. Luke and St. Paul and Grace Cathedral giving Charleston the town with the most changes ringing in the country. The church holds the "Original List of Persons of Quality, 1600 - 1700" prepared by John Camden Hotton. George Washington and Robert E. Lee sat in pew 43 in 1791 and 1862, respectively.

properties.Name: Fireproof Building
properties.Description: 100 Meeting St. Fireproof Building. Construction was completed in 1826. It is believed to be the oldest fire-resistant building in the U.S. Mills used as little wood as possible in the design. Barrel and groin vaults were used instead of wooden beams. The building was originally called the Charleston District Record Building. In 1955 the building became the headquarters of the South Carolina Historical Society.

properties.Name: Quaker Burial Ground
properties.Description: 101 Meeting St. Quaker Burial Ground. The Quaker community sold to Charleston County the land it owned at 136 King Street around 1970. The remains of those who were buried at the site were re-interred at the Court House Square. Their names appear on a plaque just to the north of the entrance gate to the square on Meeting Street. The names include Mary Fisher (1623-1698) and Daniel Latham. Fisher married a Quaker minister, William Bayley, in 1662. He died in 1675 while traveling to Barbados. Fisher then married John Crosse on Sept., 19, 1678. They had three children and then moved from Southwark, England, to Charleston. Crosse died in 1687, and Mary died one year later. Fisher attempted to convert the likes of Sultan Mehmed IV (1648-1687) to Quakerism. Daniel Latham was the Paul Revere of Charleston. He rode from Charleston to Philadelphia to inform the Continental Congress that the English had been defeated at the Battle of Sullivan's Island on June 28, 1776.

properties.Name: Hibernian Hall
properties.Description: 105 Meeting St. Hibernian Hall. Irishmen founded the Hibernian Society in 1801. The president is elected annually and must alternate between a Catholic and Protestant. The hall was completed in 1840. A piece of stone from the Giant's Causeway was brought from County Antrim and placed on the portico in 1851. The portico had to be re-built after the earthquake in 1886. An Irish harp appears over the panel above the door and the overthrow of the iron gates. Christopher Werner likely did the ironwork.

properties.Name: Standard Oil Gas Station
properties.Description: 108 Meeting St. Standard Oil Gas Station. Standard Oil knocked down three houses, including Gabriel Manigault's mansion, to build a filling station at 108 Meeting in 1930. The development was the impetus for the Board of Architectural Review (BAR). The board was officially established on Oct. 13, 1931. It was the first government body of its kind in the United States. Today, there are two boards, one for small (BAR-S) and one for large (BAR-L) projects. The key proponent for the creation of the BAR was the Preservation Society of Charleston (PSC). But it was the Historic Charleston Foundation that purchased the Standard Oil gas station in 1985 and converted it into the Frances R. Edmunds Preservation Center.

properties.Name: Mills House Hotel
properties.Description: 115 Meeting St. Mills House Hotel. Otis Mills built the first hotel at this site in 1853. It was five stories and had 125 rooms. It was also the first large building in the city to have running water and steam heat. Workers at the hotel spared the building from a city fire in 1861 by hanging wet blankets outside of the windows. Robert E. Lee, Pierre G.T. Beauregard and Theodore Roosevelt are listed among the hotel's guests. The hotel was torn down in 1968 due to termite damage. Banker Richard Jenrette (1929-2018) was among those who invested in the current "Big Pink Hotel." The building is in the same style as the previous one. Although fiberglass was used for the exterior instead of terra cotta, and the current building is two stories higher than the previous one and has 218 rooms. The hotel is currently owned by the RLJ Lodging Trust and is a part of Hilton Corp.'s Curio Collection.

properties.Name: Site of the South Carolina Institute Hall
properties.Description: 134 Meeting St. Site of the South Carolina Institute Hall. The South Carolina Institute Hall was built in 1855. It seated up to 2,500. On Dec. 20, 1860, South Carolina delegates met at the hall to vote on seceding from the Union. The count was in favor 169-0! The building then become known as Secession Hall. The building went up in flames one year later.

properties.Name: Gibbes Memorial Art Gallery
properties.Description: 135 Meeting St. Gibbes Memorial Art Gallery. The Carolina Art Association was established in 1857. Upon the death of James Shoolbred Gibbes (1819-1888), he left a gift to the CAA and the City of Charleston to build the museum that is named after him. Paintings by Benjamin West (1738-1820), Charles Willson Peale (1741-1827), Gilbert Stuart (1755-1828), Edward Greene Malbone (1777-1807), Rembrandt Peale (1778-1860), Charles Fraser (1782-1860), Thomas Sully (1783-1872), and Samuel F. B. Morse (1791 - 1872) are a part of the gallery's collection.

properties.Name: Charleston Gas Light Company
properties.Description: 141 Meeting St. Charleston Gas Light Company. The building was completed in 1878. The company was incorporated in 1846 and began lighting the streets of Charleston in 1848. The South Carolina Electric and Gas Co. now occupies the building.

properties.Name: Circular Congregation Church
properties.Description: 150 Meeting St. Circular Congregation Church. "Dissenters" of the Church of England formed a congregation in Charles Towne from 1680-1685. Members were primarily English Congregationalists, Scots Presbyterians, and French Huguenots. All of them were free white people. They constructed a building close to present-day 150 Meeting St. and called it the "meeting house." The street on which the meeting house was built became known as Meeting House Street which was then shortened to Meeting Street. There was neither an official name for the building nor the congregation that gathered in the building. The first Intendant of Charleston was Richard Hutson (1748-1795). His father was a pastor at the meeting house. The title of Intendant (which was non-paying) was later changed to Mayor. Wardens became known as Aldermen. The British used the meeting house as a hospital during the Revolutionary War. The first Circular Congregation Church was constructed on the site from 1804-1806. It could seat 2,000 people. Robert Mills was the designer. It burned in 1861. The church standing today is made out of bricks from the previous church. The church is not round but tri-apsidial.

properties.Name: Site of the Carteret Bastion
properties.Description: 155 Meeting St. Site of the Carteret Bastion. 155 Meeting was the northwest corner of the city's walls when they were built beginning in 1703. A bronze plaque hangs on the building at the northwest corner of Meeting and Horlbeck Alley that marks the location of Carteret Bastion. The bastion was named after George Carteret (1610-1680). Carteret was one of the eight Lord Proprietors.

properties.Name: Market Hall
properties.Description: 188 Meeting St. Market Hall. Most of what was bought and sold at The City Market was meat. Sheep and bull skulls decorate the Market Hall's stucco frieze. In 2010, $5.5 million was spent to renovate Market Hall. The 2nd floor of the Market Hall now houses the Confederate Museum and is the office for the Charleston Chapter of the United Daughters of the Confederacy.

properties.Name: Charleston City Market
properties.Description: City Market. The Pinckney family owns the land where the City Market has been developed. Like much of the rest of the peninsula, the land was primarily creeks and marsh. The family is allowing the city to occupy the land with the contingency that it be used for a market area. Otherwise the land reverts back to the family. In 1788, the creeks and marsh were filled to create an avenue 100 feet wide. In 1788, beef was primarily sold when the market first opened as "Centre Market." Then produce was added. Fish started to be sold once the market reached East Bay. Slaves were not sold in the City Market. Before it was prohibited to sell slaves in the streets, the slave trade occurred mostly on Broad St. between Church and East Bay or the western end of Tradd, i.e. "the usual place." All around the City Market were the "Charleston eagles." The eagles were actually Turkey and Black vultures that picked over meat scraps and piles of offal and carcasses. An ordinance was passed forbidding harm to the birds because of the sanitary role they played in the town.

properties.Name: Charleston Place
properties.Description: 209-235 Meeting St. Charleston Place. The Charleston Place Hotel project first opened in 1986 as the Omni Charleston Place. The property has since had various owners. In 1995, the property became The Charleston Place and Orient Express Hotel.  In 2014, the hotel became Charleston Place, A Belmond Hotel. In 2021, Ben Navarro purchased the property. He is the founder and CEO of an investment company called Sherman Financial. Navarro also owns a tennis facility on Daniel Island that includes the Credit One Bank Stadium. His daughter, Emma, is a highly ranked professional tennis player. The hotel has 434 guest rooms.

properties.Name: Central Fire Station and Courtenay Square
properties.Description: 262 Meeting St. Central Fire Station and Courtenay Square. The fire station was built from 1887-1888, just after the devastating earthquake of 1886. The earthquake damaged 2,000 buildings, sparked fires all across the town, and caused the death of 60-100 people. The drill tower beside the building was built in 1916 and closed in 1935. The pavilion in Courtenay Square was built in 1885. Courtenay Square is named in honor of William Ashmead Courtenay who served as the mayor of Charleston from 1879-1888.

properties.Name: Trinity Methodist
properties.Description: 275 Meeting St. Trinity Methodist. The church was constructed by a Presbyterian congregation from 1848-1850. Trinity Methodist Church purchased the church in 1926. Trinity Methodist Church was organized as the Trinity Primitive Methodist Church in 1791.

properties.Name: Washington Light Infantry Headquarters
properties.Description: 289 Meeting St. Washington Light Infantry Headquarters. The building was originally constructed as the Deutsche Freundschafts Bund Hall. The building has also been used as a site for the United Service Organization (USO) and a Masonic Temple. Today it is the headquarters for the Washington Light Infantry (2nd floor) and office space (ground floor). The Washington Light Infantry was organized in 1807. It is one of the nation's oldest militia units.

properties.Name: F. Mitchell Johnson Physical Education Center
properties.Description: 303 Meeting St. F. Mitchell Johnson Physical Education Center. The center is at the corner of George St. and Meeting St. Much of the center replaced the Radcliffe-King mansion at 22-24 George Street. The mansion was one of Charleston's most important Federal houses. Thomas Radcliffe died at sea in 1806 shortly after the mansion was constructed. Upon the death of his wife, Lucretia, the house was purchased by Mitchell King. The land all around the house has since been developed and is now known as the neighborhood of Radcliffborough. In 1881, the High School of Charleston on 55 Society moved into the Radcliffe-King mansion and remained there until 1934. The College of Charleston purchased the site and demolished the mansion on Oct. 27, 1938, to build a gymnasium. The building was funded by the Works Progress Administration as the College of Charleston's first indoor athletic facility. The center is now the location for the college's Department of Health, Education, and Human Recourses and is replete with courts for volleyball, basketball, badminton, racquetball, tennis, dance studios, weight rooms, and running tracks.

properties.Name: Connelley’s Funeral Home and Residence
properties.Description: 309 Meeting St. Connelley’s Funeral Home and Residence. Connelley's Funeral Home was South Carolina's first licensed mortuary. The coffins were made around the corner on Burns Lane. Condominiums have since replaced funeral services.

properties.Name: Federal Building
properties.Description: 334 Meeting St. Federal Building. The building was known as the L. Mendel Rivers Building upon completion. South Carolina's 1st congressional district elected L. Mendel Rivers (1905-1970) to the U.S. House of Representatives for almost 15 terms. He strongly supported the Vietnam War. He referred to himself as "The Granddaddy of the War Hawks" and promoted the use of nuclear weapons against the North Vietnamese. Much of the large amount of money that the Federal government spends today on defense in Charleston County was initiated by Rivers. The Federal government vacated the Rivers building in 1999 after Hurricane Floyd damaged the building and exposed the building's asbestos. In 2006, real estate developer John Dewberry acquired the property and spent eight years turning the building into a hotel that is named The Dewberry.

properties.Name: The Old Citadel
properties.Description: 337 Meeting St. The Old Citadel. To deter further attempts at rebellion after Denmark Vesey was hanged in 1822, an arsenal was built. The building was a two-story brick building around a courtyard at Meeting and Calhoun. Then In 1842, the state legislature established the South Carolina Military Academy. The academy consisted of an Arsenal Academy in Charleston and an Arsenal Academy in Columbia. In 1844, the arsenal building at Meeting and Calhoun was converted into a school building for the Arsenal Academy. Since the academy looked more like a fortress, it was not long until the school was re-named The Citadel. The third floor and wings were added around 1850. Some contend that the shots students of The Citadel took at the Union supply ship called The Star of the West were the first shots of the Civil War. The Arsenal Academy in Columbia never re-opened after the Union burned it down in 1865. Union soldiers did not burn The Citadel when they reached Charleston. They closed the school and occupied the building from 1865-1881. The Citadel was re-opened in 1882. In 1910, a fourth floor was added. In 1922, the school was relocated to a campus that was built on the northwest side of Charleston along the Ashley River. The address for The Citadel is now 171 Moultrie Street. The arsenal building that was turned into The Citadel is now known as The Old Citadel. Embassy Suites currently operates The Old Citadel as a part of its chain of hotels

properties.Name: Citadel Square Baptist Church
properties.Description: 338 Meeting St. Citadel Square Baptist Church. The church was built after the Fourth Baptist Church and the Morris Street Baptist Church merged in 1855 and purchased the site. Before it was named Marion Square, the square to the west of the site was called Citadel Square. Once the church was completed, it was named the Citadel Square Baptist Church. The height of its steeple was 220'. (Not to be outdone, St. Matthew's constructed its church in 1867 on the other side of Marion Square with a steeple that reaches the height of 265'.) A hurricane blew the steeple off of the Citadel Square Baptist Church in 1885. The church today is the one that appears after even more damage was inflicted by the earthquake of 1886 and Hurricane Hugo in 1989.

properties.Name: Second Presbyterian
properties.Description: 342 Meeting St. Second Presbyterian. When built, the church was just outside the city's limits. The congregation purchased the site from the Wragg family who developed much of the suburb known as Wraggborough. Therefore the corporate name of the church is The Second Presbyterian Church of Charleston and Its Suburbs. The church's first minister was Andrew Flinn, thus the church is also known informally as "Flinn's Church." It is the fourth oldest church in Charleston. Hurricane Hugo ripped off the the entire roof in 1989. The roof is back on, and a steeple is being added. When the steeple is finished, it will be the church building's first.

properties.Name: Joseph Manigault House
properties.Description: 350 Meeting St. Joseph Manigault House. Joseph Manigault (1763-1843) was the son of Elizabeth Wragg Manigault (1736-1773) and Peter Manigault (1731-1773). By 1770, Peter Manigault was likely the wealthiest man in England's North American colonies. Nathaniel Heyward (1766-1851) and Peter and Elizabeth Manigault's daughter, Henrietta, amassed over 20 plantations in South Carolina's Lowcountry. When Joseph Manigault built his house, it would have been considered a suburban home in the present-day neighborhood of Wraggborough. Wraggborough is named after Elizabeth Manigault's father, Joseph Wragg (1698-1751). Joseph Wragg became England's leader in the slave trade after breaking the English crown's monopoly on the business. Joseph Manigault's brother, Gabriel (1758-1809) designed the house. It is one of the most important Adamesque-style houses in the country. The brick is in a Flemish bond. The roof is hipped. There is a layer of lime between the floor and subfloor to prevent decay and to guard against insects. The Society for the Preservation of Old Dwellings was organized to rescue the house in 1920. The house was sold at public auction in 1933 and purchased by Princess Henrietta Pignatelli. She then donated the house to the Charleston Museum. At the south end of the house stands a structure that is unique to Charleston. It is a gate temple with a pedimented portico and circular bell roof.

properties.Name: The Charleston Museum
properties.Description: 360 Meeting St. The Charleston Museum. The museum was founded on Jan. 12, 1773, and is considered the first museum in North America. Charles Cotesworth Pinckney served as the museum's first curator. It was not until Nov. of 1824 that the museum had a dedicated structure for its collection. The museum was on Chalmers St. and was called the Museum of South Carolina. From 1828 until 1847, the museum was located at the Medical Collge of South Carolina (present-day MUSC). In 1848, the museum was moved to the College of Charleston and became known as the Museum of the College of Charleston. Francis S. Holmes served as the museum's first curator. In 1907, the museum was moved to the Thompson Auditorium on Rutledge Ave. and became known as The Charleston Museum. Laura Bragg was named the museum's director in 1920. She was the first woman in the country to direct a public museum. The museum was moved from the Thompson Auditorium to its current location in 1980. The Thompson Auditorium burned the next year. One of the more dramatic exhibits at The Charleson Museum is a model of the CSS Hunley that can be seen on the northeast corner of Calhoun and Meeting. The Hunley with its crew of 21 perished after sinking the Union USS Housatonic on February 17, 1864.

properties.Name: Montagu Street
properties.Description: Named after Sir Charles Greville Montagu (1741-1784). Montagu served as a Royal governor from 1766-1768.

properties.Name: 26 Montagu St.
properties.Description: Classic 19th century Charleston single house. The rehabilitation of the house was the Charleston Preservation Society's Hard Hat Tour in the fall of 2022.

properties.Name: 54 Montagu St.
properties.Description: In 1795, eleven lots on the estate of the late John Harleston were divided among his three daughters. Mrs. Jane Rutledge was allotted the 54 Montagu Street property. In 1801, Isaac Motte Darte, an attorney and factor, purchased the lot and built his 2 ½ story frame house set on a raised basement. A typical double house set facing the street, the structure is of the Federal architectural period and many of the interior details and furnishings are associated with the Adam brothers, British architects and interior designers whose work was very influential in the United States. In 1823 a Gothic Revival carriage house was built in the rear. In 1995, this property was a virtual wasteland consisting of two derelict buildings and a large garden lost to asphalt paving for a parking lot. After the hard surface had been removed, sixteen truckloads of top soil were spread to provide a planting base. The owner set about designing and executing his garden plan with fencing, walls, and hedges much like a contractor would create the walls of a house. He then divided the property into seven rooms.

properties.Name: Theodore Gaillard House
properties.Description: 60 Montagu St. Theodore Gaillard House. Gaillard was a rice grower and trader. He bought the three lots that comprise the present-day property. Gaillard sold the house and property to Jacob Read in 1817 for $11,000. Read died four years later. The house and property was then sold to James Shoolbred. In 1851, the house became the property of Washington Jefferson Bennett, the son of Gov. Thomas Bennett (1781-1865). The Bennetts operated rice and lumber mills along the nearby Mill Pond. When General Robert E. Lee visited Charleston after the Civil War, he gave a speech from the house's second story portico. The interior consists of rooms with mantelpieces with intricate Adamesque, composite ornamentation that represent foxhunts, undersea shells and plants, and Grecian motifs such as classic urn sprays and swags. The elaborate plaster cornices throughout the house include a mix of vine scrolls, cornucopias, anthemion (honeysuckle) wreaths, husks, palmetto fans and paterae ornamentation. The house had a massive restoration from 2007-2011. The tack house and the wall and wood gate on the Gadsden Street side of the property are how they appear in Alice Ravenel Huger Smith's drawings in her book, The Dwelling Houses of Charleston.

properties.Name: Murray Boulevard
properties.Description: Named after Andrew Buist Murray (1844-1928). The street was constructed from 1911-15. Murray paid for half of the street's development. Murray was the adopted son of W. Jefferson Bennett.

properties.Name: Archibald Baker Jr. House
properties.Description: 36 Murray Blvd. Archibald Baker Jr. House. Dr. Archibald Baker Sr. (1862-1934) and Dr. Lawrence R. Craig founded the Baker Hospital in 1912. The hospital was located at the southwest corner of Ashley and Wentworth. Baker became the sole owner of the hospital in 1916. He lived at 70 Murray Boulevard. Upon Baker's death, the hospital was re-commissioned as The Baker Memorial Sanatorium. Baker's son, Dr. Archibald Baker Jr. (1895-1951), managed the sanatorium until the end of World War II.

properties.Name: Orange Street
properties.Description: Orange Street is named after Orange Garden. The borders of the Orange Garden were Broad (north), Tradd (south), and King (east). The park had wide walkways and was bordered by flower beds and hedges of Seville orange trees. There were also refreshment booths and a stage for music performances. The city began selling off the park beginning in the 1760’s. Edward Rutledge began building his house on the northwestern edge of the land in 1760. Silversmith Alexander Petrie cut a street from Edward Rutledge's house south to Tradd in 1767 and named it Orange Street. He then began selling lots on the western side of the street. On April 12, 1768, South Carolina's provincial government passed legislation that called for the construction of a canal connecting the west end of Broad Street to the Ashley River. The marshes bordering the canal were to remain forever as common ground for the public. Any attempt at using the space for any other purpose was "absolutely null and void." Where the marshes were is now where Colonial Lake is.

properties.Name: The Simons Tenements
properties.Description: 9-11 Orange St. The Simons Tenements. Samuel Gilman (1819-1858), the pastor at the Unitarian Church, lived at 11 Orange St. Gilman also wrote "Fair Harvard." Gilman's wife, Caroline, wrote the continent's first newspaper for children. It was called The Rosebud.

properties.Name: Pitt Street
properties.Description: Pitt Street is named after William "the elder" Pitt (1708-1778). Pitt was instrumental in repealing the Stamp Act of 1765. A statue of Pitt is on display in the Charleston County Judicial Center.

properties.Name: Rivers Green at the College of Charleston
properties.Description: 52-54 Pitt St. Rivers Green at the College of Charleston. Rivers Green is named after John Rivers. Rivers Green and the Addlestone Library were once a cemetery. The Brown Fellowship Society managed the cemetery. The society was founded in 1790 by freemen of African descent. The society sold the cemetery to the Roman Catholic Diocese in 1957. The grave stones were moved to Magnolia Cemetery, and then the Bishop England High School at 203 Calhoun was expanded. Bishop England High School re-located to Daniel Island in 1998. The Roman Catholic Diocese then sold the property to the College of Charleston. The Addlestone Library at 205 Calhoun Street and Rivers Green were completed in 2005.

properties.Name: Bethel Methodist Church
properties.Description: 57 Pitt St. Bethel Methodist Church. The Old Bethel Church used to stand at 57 Pitt. The white members of the congregation moved the church to 200 Calhoun in order to build the church that stands today at 57 Pitt. The black members of Bethel Methodist then gathered at 200 Calhoun. The parking lot in the back of the church and the backyard of 88 Smith was once the Ephrath Cemetery. It is the burial site for as many as 3,600 people of African descent.

properties.Name: Prioleau Street
properties.Description: The name is pronounced "PRAY-low". The street was cut in the 1790s through land that Frenchman Samuel Prioleau Jr. (1717-1792) owned.

properties.Name: Queen Street
properties.Description: The street is named after Caroline of Ansbach. England's King George I died on June 11, 1727. On October 11 of the same year, George I's third son, George Augustus (1683-1760), and his wife, Catherine of Ansbach (1683-1737), were crowned King George II and queen consort, respectively, at Westminster Abbey.  Prior to being named Queen Street, the street was the Grand Modell's Dock Street.

properties.Name: Thomas Elfe House
properties.Description: 54 Queen St. Thomas Elfe House. Elfe was a premier cabinetmaker. He spent 10 years building his house at 54 Queen. He left eight years worth of accounting records that shows more than 1,500 pieces of furniture being sold mainly to Charleston's upper class. The house has been featured on House and Garden TV (HGTV) and in the magazine Early American Life.

properties.Name: Charleston County Parking Garage
properties.Description: 80 Queen St. Charleston County Parking Garage. Quaker John Archdale held a grant on this site on which once stood three Quaker meeting houses. The last of the three burned in 1861. The property remained in the ownership of the Quaker community until it was purchased by Charleston County in 1970. The address for the west side of the garage is 136 King Street. The remains of all those who were buried at the site were re-interred at Court House Square (101 Meeting Street).

properties.Name: US Electric Illuminating Co.
properties.Description: 94 Queen St. US Electric Illuminating Co. was organized in 1881 and was the first to offer electric service in Charleston. The company folded when the city decided not to use electric rather than gas for its street lighting. Electric began looking a lot more attractive after gas lines exploded across the town during the earthquake of 1886.

properties.Name: Race Street
properties.Description: There were once two racecourses in Charleston. The first one was called Newmarket. Races were first conducted at the track around 1760. Racing moved to the Washington Race Course in 1792 and were held there each February until 1882. The oval that the horses ran on is now Mary Murray Drive. The former infield is Hampton Park. Race Street was named for its close proximity to both tracks.

properties.Name: Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church
properties.Description: 28 Race St. Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church. The first Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church was built at Fishburne and St. Philip's in 1911. It was the first Greek Orthodox Church in South Carolina. That corner was obliterated by the construction of Interstate 26. The Greek Orthodox Church moved to 28 Race upon the completion of its new church building in 1952. The church's Trinity Hall is at 34 Race St.

properties.Name: Rutledge Avenue
properties.Description: The street is named after John Rutledge (1730-1800). Rutledge was President and Governor of South Carolina, delegate to the Continental Congress and U.S. Constitutional Convention, Chief Justice of the S.C. Supreme Court and Chief Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court.

properties.Name: Isaac Jenkins Mikell House
properties.Description: 94 Rutledge Ave. Isaac Jenkins Mikell House. Mikell grew crops on land he owned on Edisto Island. He also went through four wives. He forgot why he married his first wife. He gained wealth and status from his second wife. He loved his third wife, Mary Martha Pope, and built for her the mansion at 94 Rutledge. The construction of the house was called “One of the most ambitious of the private dwellings of Charleston.” Mikell married a fourth wife to take care of him in his old age. The house served as the Charleston County Free Library from 1935-1960. It is currently a single family home.

properties.Name: Gibbon House
properties.Description: 97 Rutledge Ave. (George) Gibbon House. Maud Gibbon (1885-1974) was the daughter of George Gibbon. After learning to play the cello, Maud began performing with Charleston's Musical Arts Club beginning in 1908. In the summer of 1919, Gibbon founded the Charleston Muscial Society. Gibbon worked from her home at 97 Rutledge organizing weekly concerts for members of the society. In 1921, the name of the society was changed to the Charleston Symphony Orchestra. The orchestra disbanded in the 1930s. Gibbon and others then founded the Charleston String Orchestra in 1936. This name lasted until it was decided to revive the Charleston Symphony Orchestra In 1942. Gibbon retired from managing and performing with the CSO in 1948. The foundation of the house was formed with bricks from Stoney Landing.

properties.Name: William Stevens Smith House
properties.Description: 101 Rutledge Ave. William Stevens Smith House. Smith was a lawyer, legislator, land owner, and crop grower. Dr. Thomas Ballard McDow (1853-1904) used the basement for his practice. It is also where he shot Francis Warrington Dawson on March 12, 1889. Dawson lived around the corner at 99 Bull Street. Dawson was the editor of the News and Courier. Dawson promoted "fusion" during Reconstruction. He used the term to encourage white voters to help elect worthy Republicans rather than boycott the polls. In 1888, Pope Leo XIII knighted Dawson to the Order of St. Gregory for his editorials against dueling. Dawson also wrote in fierce opposition to lynching. On March 12, 1889, Dawson entered the office of Dr. Thomas B. McDow. Rather than doctoring Dawson, McDow shot Dawson twice and killed him after accusing him of making "dishonorable advances" towards the governess of his children. McDow was acquitted of murder on the claim of self-defense. The basement today is a dentist's office.

properties.Name: Thomson Auditorium
properties.Description: 121 Rutledge Ave. Thomson Auditorium. In 1893, John Thomson's estate left the City of Charleston $100,000 to spend as it saw fit. In 1898, the city directed the money towards the construction of the Thomson Auditorium in anticipation of the reunion for the United Confederate Veterans. The auditorium was built in 90 days and was able to seat 8,000 people. From 1907-1981, the building was the home for the Charleston Museum. The Charleston Museum moved to its new home on Meeting Street just before its building on Rutledge Avenue burned, the remains of which are visible today.

properties.Name: Cannon Park
properties.Description: 131 Rutledge Ave. Cannon Park. Bennett’s Mill Pond was filled in from 1880-1900 and designated Cannon’s Mall. The mall was named after Daniel Cannon. Cannon and the Bennett family operated saw mills in partnership on Bennett's Mill Pond. In January of 1853, Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903) visited Charleston. He was not impressed. He considered Charleston’s civic elections "entirely contests of money and personal influence” and noted that oligarchs dominated civic planning. They maintained elaborate private gardens concealed behind walls and mansions while designating minimal space for public parks and recreation. Despite the criticism, the city later consulted with Olmsted's sons, John Charles Olmsted (1852-1920) and Frederick Law Olmsted Jr. (1870-1957) to develop a park plan for Cannon’s Mall. It was never used. Thomson's Auditorium was built on the site instead, the remains of which are still visible today. During high-water events, the rest of the park reverts mostly to a pond. Beginning in 1947, Herman Brüning offered "His Fellow Citizens of Charleston" a safe drink of water at the north end of the park.

properties.Name: Johnson-Wilber House
properties.Description: 156 Rutledge Ave. (William) Johnson- Wilber House. William Johnson (1771-1834) lived for many years in the house. Johnson served in the S.C. House of Representatives. In 1804, President Thomas Jefferson appointed Johnson to the U.S. Supreme Court. His opinions favoring a strong federal government turned him into a social outcast in Charleston. He moved to Brooklyn in 1834 only to die soon thereafter from an unsuccessful surgery.

properties.Name: McBee House
properties.Description: 172 Rutledge Ave. (Mary Vardrine) McBee House. Patrick Duncan built the villa from 1802- 1816. It was also the residence of Charles Otto Witte from 1870-1907. Witte was president of the Exchange Bank and Trust Company when the bank was built at 39 Broad. Witte was a native of Germany and served as a consul for the country for 50 years. Wilhelm II knighted Witte in 1907. McBee used the house to found The Ashley Hall School in 1909. Alumni of the all-girls school include Former First Lady Barbara Bush (1925-2018), mezzo-soprano D'Anna Fortunato (b. 1945), and authors Madeleine L'Engle (1918-2007), Josephine Pinckney (1895-1957), and Josephine Humphreys (b. 1945).

properties.Name: Smith Street
properties.Description: Named for Benjamin Smith (1717-1770. Smith was a slave trader, land owner, ship owner, banker, and politician. He resided at 49 Church with his wife, Mary Wragg. Other houses he built were 51-53 Broad.

properties.Name: Robertson-Pickens House
properties.Description: 34 Smith St. (George) Robertson- (Samuel B.) Pickens House. Robertson was a Scottish merchant. He also built the house a 1 Meeting. Robertson and his wife, Mary Joanna, left the property to their niece, Anna Ingraham Pickens. Anna was married to Samuel B. Pickens (1839-91). Pickens was a member of The Citadel's class of 1861. He was also a member of the cadet unit that fired the first shots at the Federal supply ship, Star of the West, that was trying to reach Ft. Sumter. Cadet G. E Haynsworth fired the first; Pickens fired the second. Some consider these first shots of the Civil War (1861-1865). Julius Jahnz became the owner of the property in 1902. The Edisto River was diverted into Charleston's water system while Jahnz was serving as the Chairman of the Commissioners of Public Works.

properties.Name: Society Street
properties.Description: The street is named for the South Carolina Society. The society purchased land along the street in 1759. In 1804, the society moved to the building it constructed at 72 Meeting. 55 Society Street used to be the High School of Charleston.

properties.Name: 4 S Adgers Wharf
properties.Description: 4 S Adgers Wharf. An extensive renovation of this former cotton warehouse was completed in 2014. Arched openings were restored for custom windows. Ornamentation that was a part of a previous renovation were stripped to approach more closely the structure's original appearance.

properties.Name: South Battery Street
properties.Description: South Battery started out as Fort Street. It was narrow and ran between Church and Meeting streets behind Broughton's Bastion. Marsh and mud flats have been filled in to create the High Battery, East Battery, and White Point Garden. In 1830, the name of the street running from East Battery to King Street was changed from Fort Street to South Battery. Residents of South Battery had their views of the Ashley River drastically reduced when construction of Murray Boulevard began in 1911.

properties.Name: Villa Margeurita
properties.Description: 4 South Battery St. Villa Margeurita. Andrew Simonds built the house for his wife Daisy Breaux. Simonds was president of the First National Bank and commodore of the Carolina Yacht Club. Breaux turned the house into a hotel in 1909 and named it the Villa Margeurita. Among the guests were Alexander Graham Bell, Henry Ford, Teddy Roosevelt, and Franklin Delano Roosevelt. An idea of the inn's extravagance was a bowl of its turtle soup that a patron would be charged hundreds in today's dollars.

properties.Name: Col. William Washington House
properties.Description: 8 South Battery. Col. William Washington House. William Washington (1752-1810) was a cousin to George Washington. William Washington fought at the Battle of Eutaw Springs and others. More battles were fought in South Carolina during the Revolutionary War than any other state/colony. Washington purchased the lot at 8 South Battery in 1785 after marrying Jane Elliott, the daughter of Charles Elliott. Charles Elliott lived at 43 Legare and was a landowner near Rantowles. Although Thomas Savage supposedly built the house in 1768. At some point a formal garden was planted to the west of the house. It has paisley-shaped beds that date back to the antebellum. Additional design has been done by Hugh and Mary Dargan. William and Jane Washington are buried in the Elliott family burial ground at Rantowles.

properties.Name: Stevens-Lathers House
properties.Description: 20 South Battery St. (Samuel N.) Stevens - (Col. Richard) Lathers House. The house was originally built as a 3-story, T-shaped neo-classical structure. Richard Lathers purchased the property in 1870. He modified the house in the style of the Second Empire. The property continued to change hands until Ernest and Nell Pringle purchased the property in 1912. On April 20, 1920, Nell Pringle and her cousin, Susan Pringle Frost, and 31 others met in the house's ballroom to begin a campaign to prevent the Joseph Manigault House at 350 Meeting Street from turning into a gas station. Frost and her supporters saved the house and ignited what is recognized today as the "Charleston Renaissance." The group continued to meet and officially formed the Society for the Preservation of Old Dwellings. The society is known today as the Preservation Society of Charleston. 20 South Battery currently operates as a boutique hotel owned by Dr. Jack Schaeffer. The Preservation Society of Charleston awarded Schaeffer the Pro Merito Carolopolis in 2020.

properties.Name: Frederick Heinz Houses
properties.Description: 36-40 South Battery St. Frederick Heinz Houses. Heinz was a baker, confectioner, and ice cream maker. He lived at 36 South Battery and built 38 and 40 South Battery as investments. Before building the houses, Heinz used the lots to operate the Battery Ice Cream Garden.

properties.Name: Wm. Gibbes House
properties.Description: 64 S Battery St. Wm. Gibbes House. The ironwork is from 1782. Gibbes led the development or “fill and build" of the peninsula's southwestern marsh areas. Fellow developers were Robert Mackenzie and George Kincaid. 64 South Battery was also once owned by Sarah (Moore) Smith. Sarah’s daughter, Mary “Polly,” was the wife of John Faucheraud Grimké. John and Mary lived at 321 E. Bay. They had fourteen children. Among them were the abolitionists Sarah Moore Grimké and Angelina Grimké Weld. The house's garden was the first project for Loutrell Briggs in Charleston.

properties.Name: Harth-Middleton House
properties.Description: 68 S Battery St. Harth (John) - (Henry A.) Middleton House. John Harth owned a lumber mill and was a land owner. He sold the property to Thomas Legare. In 1843, Henry A. Middleton bought the house and enlarged it. Henry A. Middleton and his family sold the house to William J. Pettus in 1917. Pettus then went about filling the marsh area of the property and planting the present-day garden.

properties.Name: St. James Methodist Church
properties.Description: 68 Spring St. St. James Methodist Church. In 1797, St. James' Chapel was established on upper King Street near Line Street. In 1816, St. James's became a part of the Methodist Episcopal Church. In 1856, the congregation sold its King Street property and began building its church at 68 Spring. It was named the Spring Street Methodist Church. The building was incomplete in 1862 when the Confederate government took it over to use it as a medical storehouse. The congregation was able to return to the church after the Civil War. The building is now owned by the Karpeles Manuscript Library Museum. It is one of nine in the country. Together they supposedly hold the largest collection of original manuscripts and documents in the world.

properties.Name: Lowndes' Grove Plantation House
properties.Description: 266 St Margaret St. Lowndes' Grove Plantation House. The first owner of the 170 acres on which the plantation house sits was Richard Cartwright. He acquired the land through a land grant from England's King Charles II in 1701. By the middle of the 18th century, John Gibbes was the owner of the land. Gibbes then sold the land to George Abbot Hall. There is record of a house being built on the property that was likely destroyed during the Revolutionary War. The land continued to change hands until William J. Lowndes became the owner in 1803. Lowndes built the house that stands today short of the front piazza and the Greek Revival arches on the ground floor. They were added by another property owner in 1830. Lowndes named the house and land Lowndes' Grove. From 1811 until his death in 1822, Lowndes represented South Carolina in the U.S. House of Representatives. By 1901, Lowndes' Grove was owned by Frederick W. Wagener who used the site for a private track for horse racing and for the South Carolina Inter-State and West Indian Exposition. During the exposition, the house was the Woman's Building by the Daughters of the American Revolution and the Colonial Dames. It is also where President Teddy Roosevelt dined when he traveled to Charleston for the exposition. In 1918, James Sottile purchased Lowndes' Grove. Sottile developed such areas as the Isle of Palms and Lowndes' Grove that enabled him to become among the country's richest men. Out of the 170 acres that was Lowndes' Grove, Sottile left the present-day block that surrounds the house. The house is used today as a venue for special events and has been featured in television programs such as "Outer Banks."

properties.Name: 2 St Michaels Alley
properties.Description: Philip Simmons fabricated the Cross & Egret Gate.

properties.Name: James L. Petigru Law Office
properties.Description: 8 St. Michaels Alley. James L. Petigru (1789-1863) Law Office. Petigru was a lawyer, politician, and jurist. He also served as an Attorney General of South Carolina and was the first president of the South Carolina Historical Society (1855). He opposed South Carolina's Ordinance of Nullification and Declaration of Secession. Petigru claimed South Carolina was “too small for a republic but too large for an insane asylum.”

properties.Name: St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church
properties.Description: 134 St Philip St. St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church. The parish was established in 1837 for Catholics living on Charleston's Neck. The construction of a wooden church began on St. Patrick's Day 1838. In 1886, the church was rolled across the street to make room for the construction of the church standing today. The old church was used as a school building. It was replaced by the present school building at 125 St. Philip Street in 1930.

properties.Name: State Street
properties.Description: The street was named Union in 1707 to commemorate the unification of England and Scotland. The name was changed to State in 1812.

properties.Name: Wagner-Trott Building
properties.Description: 30 State St. Wagner-Trott Building. Grocer Jeremiah O'Brien was among the building's tenants. After the passage of The Dispensary Act, O'Brien operated a saloon on the first floor that was regarded by many as the most notorious "blind tiger." Police made frequent raids on the establishment. Greek merchant Arthur A. Pappas used the same space to operate the "Queen Lunch Room" during the prohibition period of the 1920's. Buckshot holes that were found in the walls of the house when it was restored in 2017 are indications of how guns and alcohol have always been an explosive mix.

properties.Name: Stoll's Alley
properties.Description: Named after blacksmith Justinus Stoll. Stoll's home was 7 Stoll's Alley. It was built around 1745. Prior to then, the street was known as Pilots Alley. Philip Simmons created a number of the alley's gates.

properties.Name: 2 Stolls Alley
properties.Description: Philip Simmons fabricated the Tulip Gate.

properties.Name: 5 Stolls Alley
properties.Description: Philip Simmons fabricated the Double Lyre Gate.

properties.Name: Archdale Street
properties.Description: Named after Quaker John Archdale (1642-1717). Owned the portion of the Grand Modell called Archdale Square. Served as Governor of the Province of Carolina, 1695-96. He was called a man of "character and ability." This would not be the opinion of Native Americans. He regarded Smallpox as a blessing from God to “To thin the Indians, in order to make more room for the English." Smallpox, Yellow Fever, malaria, and other sicknesses once earned for the Charleston the moniker the "Charnel House."

properties.Name: 75 Anson St
properties.Description: 75 Anson. Joseph Legare House. Legare owned land and grew crops along the Santee River. A third story was added in 1838 and then removed in 1974.

properties.Name: DuBose Heyward House.
properties.Description: 9 St. Michael's Alley. DuBose Heyward House.
